People brought out the chipped ones and the ridiculous ones, the cups with praise printed on them for jubilees not their own and the one without a handle that a grandfather would not part with because his hand had decided where to hold, and they set them on the table that Magdalene and Mr. Bobbin had brought out, which was the one that had never liked to live indoors and had longed for a market all its life and had been obliged to be respectable. On the table was laid a cloth that did not match anything and therefore matched the town.

They wrote, not in the blue books, but on paper that had wrapped a ham and on the back of a notice about Methodist teas and on one page of the Hampshire Chronicle that had got loose from binding because Magdalene had let it go. They wrote what they brought: I will come and sit at your window and say nothing on Wednesday. They wrote what they needed: my husband will not speak to me because the Queen died and he thinks being sad must be bigger than a kitchen and I would like someone to tell him the kitchen can hold the Queen if you open the doors. They wrote in ugly hands and in beautiful ones and in a child’s block capitals, and Eliza wrote a note that said, as if daring someone to disagree, I am very bad at funerals; I can carry chairs. The list of verbs began to pick up in its fibers a new category of action that had not been set in type and probably never would be because the world would not consider it decent: the work of listening while someone fails to tell the truth and forgives himself.

That afternoon, when it would have been a pretty cruelty to do nothing and watch a town exhaust itself on its own virtue, Vellum sent the inspectors to the church. They came with a ledger that asked Elijah Grieves to account for how many bells had been rung for how many griefs and whether the bells had resounded equally for the rich and the eating of sausages yesterday, and Elijah took the book in both hands and regarded it as if it were a coal shovel asking to be consulted on weddings. He set it down. He wrote in a hand so slow and exact that any inspector would be obliged to watch until boredom did what truth could not, and he wrote: the bell rings the same for anyone who held a spoon. Then he added: the bell rings the same for anyone who did not, and he underlined did not because he understood that grief sometimes has nothing to do with having had a thing and much to do with having been promised and never given.

Quill, who had no respect for ledgers and a professional interest in paper that presumed, leaped onto an inspector’s lap and placed both paws squarely on the word appropriation before the man could read it, and stayed there until his full cat weight pressed it through the paper and into the man’s trousers as a little shame. The inspector tried to move him and could not because there are laws in this world that only cats enforce, and finally he laughed helplessly and let the laughing go on two seconds longer than he should have because it was not the tone pamphlets require. When he stood up at last, the word had transferred to his shirt and he would have to go home before he could be seen enforcing anything else, and this, too, was a mercy the town pretended not to understand.

For his countercharm, Elias did not bring a broom because brooms would offend men who believed in ledgers; he brought a ledger bigger than theirs. He took the book Mrs. Bell kept under her bed and carried the kettle on top of it the way he had told her to, and he laid it on the commons table open at the page where the babies’ names had been rearranged in Vellum’s pretty formation and straightened again with twine. “Write your own kindnesses to yourselves,” he said, and the town looked at him as if he had suggested that men put their hands in their own pockets and share out their money to the person who always forgot he deserved any. He nodded at Mr. Crisp’s daughter because he was not above calling in a terror when he needed one, and Eliza wrote at the top of a clean page with the printshop’s ugly pen in an ugly ink: I forgive myself for not liking funerals, as long as I carry chairs, and she signed it, and the ink looked better at once for having been given a bad job to do and doing it with an honest back.

He made a thing with string and spoons, because words are not everything and metal is next to truth if you ask the right question. He took spoons, which were the same spoons men have argued over for a thousand years, and he tied string to them, and he laid them in a bowl in the center of the table, and he told anyone who came to the commons that if they left without taking one, he would be cross. Hester took a spoon, because Hester would take anything that looked as if it might become a weapon later, and she put it in her pocket and made it ring when she walked. Mr. Bobbin tied his string around his wrist because he did not trust himself to keep hold of things that were not heavy. Mrs. Hardesty put hers under the counter because she had a way of reaching for sharp words and she wanted to grab metal first. The spoons knocked together when the wind came, and the sound they made was the kind of small music that rearranges a miser into a person who remembers that the spoon in his hand is meant for soup he intends to share.

Vellum tried boring them in the afternoon, because Quill had predicted boredom, and a man will always try the tactic you least fear when he thinks you’ve become clever. He sent a procession. It was not the sort of procession that makes boys throw their caps and girls adjust their collars; it was the sort of procession that a man invents when he has never been celebrated and suspects that celebration is a punishment. They came with white bands around their arms and white cloths tied to sticks and white feathers on their hats that made their hats look ashamed, and they walked without a band and without a stride and without anything to carry properly and they asked that people admire the Quiet. They did not speak. They did not sing. They did not shuffle. They were the kind of silence that wave at windows and wait to be invited in to sit on chairs and tell women their grief is untidy.

Elias did not tell Hester she must not do what she was thinking. He let her run into the back of the procession with bells tied to her ankles, because Hester had learned from Elijah Grieves that bells belong to wrists and rope and people, not to schedules, and she made a noise like a baby storm and the white hats bobbed in agitation like mushrooms in uncertain weather. Mr. Bobbin, whose instrument does not take to being asked for high-mindedness, took out his fiddle and played badly on purpose because badness is sometimes a holy act, and the procession had to step in time to avoid looking ridiculous and then looked ridiculous anyway because a song had attached itself and they had not been made to hold one.

When the white came to the church, the vicar stepped out and spoke to it like a man who had been interrupted while buttering bread. “No,” he said, and he said it with an old west wind in his voice, the kind that knocks apples and leaves them fit for jelly and tells men not to argue about fruit. “You may come in when you have something to carry. We do not admire emptiness on purpose. We admire it by mistake, when we had meant to make soup and the cupboard argued.” The Quiet did not know what to do with being told that it had nothing in its hands. It had been in rooms where being blank earns praise. It had been in rooms where men have made their faces into a refusal to cry and had been congratulated. It had not been in a place where being silent was not a virtue to be paraded but a space to be held while someone else finds her breath.

By late day, the coupons had lost their paper shine and had become merely paper. They were useful to light stoves and to write shopping lists and occasionally to stick under a table leg that wobbled because a man had wished to have his cupboard stand level and the floor refused. Elias took the book from his pocket and tore out the Special Allowance that said for grief, and he went to Mrs. Bell in between calls because he had the offense in his hands and could not carry it another hour, and he laid it on her table and put the kettle on top of it, and he did not speak because there are things you must not say in the presence of a woman whose day keeps people alive. He washed his hands without being asked and took the chair by the stove and scraped his nails carefully with the back of the knife because blood hides in them and you must show it a way out. Mrs. Bell saw him make a ritual and felt, in her elbows, a lessening of something no man had put there. She would not say thank you. She would say breathe to a girl with a long night ahead, and the thank you would be in not dying.

That night, for the first time since he had moved into the lower room, Vellum came up into the air. He did not mean to, which is how you know he was not yet lost to cunning altogether. He brought no paper. He brought the point of his nose and the fragile edge of his pride and stood at the corner where the field with the sign Parcel 7 looked at the hedge and pretended not to be jealous. He looked at the chalk written on his map through the window and at the chalk on the ground that boys had made into boxes with words in them because the big words kept their feet under them when they jumped. He wondered whether he had written the word necessary too many times today and if he had, whether that made it less so. He had known hunger was a bowl you do not talk about; he had not known kindness was a bowl you must talk into or it goes hard on the edges and does not pour.

Elias met him there not because he had guessed at Vellum’s steps but because his own had brought him round the circuit of his day and landed at that corner the way a penny stops because a nail is under the tablecloth. He stood a little way off and did not say “you have come out,” because men who have been under so long think you are mocking them. He stood with his hands in his pockets and thought of his mother’s ribbon and of Short John’s hands and of the vicar’s head when it had been bowed for an instant today at the word river and then lifted because it had been asked to say Anton. When he spoke, he did not say a clever line, because cleverness serves only the first nice minute and then grows hungry.

“You cannot make a scarcity of what breath does,” he said. He said it to the hedge, because hedges understand things better than men when men are being watched. “You can make counting of the parts of it. You can put values on the edges so that someone with cold fingers can be persuaded it is warmer to have a list than a woman's hand. You can convince a boy that it is better to be thanked by a ribbon than by the look on his father’s face when the wood is in. But it is breath. It will go into whatever room will let it, and if you shut the doors, it will push under, and if you seal that, it will go out the chimney and come down next door and the next town will name its fields and sing badly and keep its grief in bowls.”

Vellum did not speak for a time, which is a form of respect in men who suspect they may not be loved and do not wish to do anything worse than they must. When he did, he kept his voice thin, perhaps because he did not know how to make it broad without sounding like someone he had hated. “My father gave my mother coupons for laughter,” he said, not looking at Elias and not looking away, because his eyes had been taught to behave at their work. “He gave her three a week and one extra at Easter and told her not to overspend because laughing made the neighbors think we were like them and he did not want to be like them. On Mondays she laughed when she burned the bread and got scolded for it because the coupon did not cover laughter at mistakes. On Saturdays she would stand by the window and look at the back yard and use them all in a swallow. I thought that was economy and grace. I thought that was how you kept a house from spilling. You will not persuade me with bowls.”

“I do not want to persuade you,” Elias said, because he had learned, slowly, that doing so can make a man hate truth for being clever. “I want to keep the town from being punished because your father ran his house like a counting book. You will go on being the sort of man whose hand writes smaller when he is ashamed. You will call it neatness and sometimes you will be right. You will look at the way people put cups down and think of putting them down in rows. No one will stop you thinking that. When you put the rows in other people’s houses you will be in my way. I will not let you. You may come and stand at the edge and watch a bowl and call it foolish and go away and not die of it. Or you may come with a cup, which would make both of us very tired. Either way, you will not count women’s laughter. It will go strange if you do.”

Vellum turned his head then, not toward Elias exactly, but toward the sound of a woman on the green laughing in a way she had been rationing her whole life, that donkey-bray surprised into grace which you hear on spring days and at funerals out of season. He watched the sound, which is a thing that can be done if you are patient, and for a second some piece of him that had been seven and had wanted to point thought very hard about climbing out of his shirt. He put his hand on his cuff, which he had whitened this morning so that no discussion of his person would take place without his consent, and he said, as if tasting does not count as appetite, “You will not think me a monster if I tell you I have written to men who will buy your fields with the numbers I have given them.”

“I will think you a clerk who has put his pen into another man’s land and expected the soil to take ink,” Elias said. He did not smile because there is no kindness in smiling at a man to whom you must say something honest. “They will come. They will carry rulers. They will stand in Daniel’s Oat and in Margaret’s Drop and ask where the lines are and expect to be told. And we will take them to the green and ask them to wait while we sing ill and ring bells wrong and feed them soup that is very good and speak the names of our dead in such a way that when they leave their rulers will have learned something unforgivable, which is that there are measures you cannot take and remain tidy. They will suspect we are untoward and be correct.”

“It will not last,” Vellum said, and his voice did not have triumph in it nor despair. It had the damp of below-rooms and a boy’s obedience. “You cannot win with bowls. A bowl breaks.”

“A bowl mends,” Elias answered, and the word, tiny and serviceable, went between them like an old coin that has passed so many hands it has become a prayer. “And even when it shatters, the floor keeps some of what was in it. You have been trying to win with pins. A pin rusts. I am not winning either, not in any way you would count. I am living long enough to know where the tea is kept. That, it turns out, is a form of victory if you have to choose one.” He inclined his head to Vellum, not as to a man he liked, which he did not, and not as to a man he pitied, which he was trying not to make into a habit, but as to a man he intended to continue to know until one of them died.

When he walked away, Quill slipped down from the hedge where he had been rude in every way a cat can be in the presence of a man who tries to regulate laughter. He wound himself between Elias’s ankles with exaggerated forgiveness, because he had climbed a field and dirtied his white feet and wished not to be told he was glorious. “He wants to be told someone will count him,” the cat said, which is as near to kindness as Quill gets with enemies who don’t have scales. “He thinks fair is numbers and not chairs carried and kettles offered and boys not told to hush. You will not persuade him, but you will make him late for his next cruelty and that matters as much as anything in a town.”

It was late when the new ledger went up, which is to say the old wall of the old posting house that no one had posted in for years because one man had been shot for the wrong thing there once upon a time and the wall had taken a dislike to messages. Tired hands with good chalk wrote on it not news and not orders and not anything that would earn anyone praise; they wrote kindnesses that had happened and the spoons that had been returned and the cups that had gone missing and had been found under beds and the chairs that had been carried and the chairs that would need carrying on Thursday because Mrs. Plumbly was coming to lay out her dead. They wrote in their own hands the line that Magdalene had learned to set and refused today and would not refuse tomorrow: already paid. Then under it, because men will be men and towns will be towns and there are rules that must be spoken and laughed at, they wrote: if you have not paid, do not fret; bring a pie.

At Elias’s table, the dot sat content as a seed in a dish and the truth card lay face down under it because truth lies better if you give it a small weight. He wrote on his list behind the broom mend and rest and then wrote borrow and lend and then wrote sing even if and then, because the day had asked more of him than a heroism and he had given it, he wrote sardines because Quill had been patient beyond reason. Quill leaped onto the chair with the look of a cat who has been promised something and intends to collect with a complaint, and he purred while he ate and made the tiny noise that sounds like tea water beginning to forgive a kettle. Andover breathed the way a house does when the baby has been put down and the father is keeping his chair quiet by force of will and the mother has taken off her shoes and will be found sleeping with one in her hand, and somewhere a man below a school put his pen down for a minute and looked at his empty hand as if it might have the right to be bare and did not know what to do with it and did nothing, which is a beginning if you have someone to make soup for you later.

On the morning the butcher’s window went blind, Elias Fiske was crouched beneath the blackthorn hedge behind Mrs. Coppin’s cottage, coaxing a teaspoon of warm honey and thyme between the paws of a hare that had mistaken iron for clover. Andover had not yet properly shaken the chill from its bones; a gray fleece lay over the town, and the Anton stream moved low and glass-green along its cut chalk banks. The hedges smelled of dew and cold mud. Elias talked as he worked, not to the hare but to the cat standing on his shoulder as if it were a prow.

“Hold steady, Quill,” he said. “One more drop and the tongue will remember it belongs inside the mouth.”

Quill’s tail whisked him on the nose. “It isn’t the hare, old man,” the cat said, voice a frostbitten whisper so it wouldn’t spook the small patient. “It’s you who forgets. Humans, I’ve noticed, a great fondness for letting bits go wandering. Keys. Tempers. Whole lives.”

“I haven’t mislaid my life,” Elias said mildly. He set down the spoon, pried the bit of iron free—some child’s nail, rusted thin—and murmured a comfort to seal the blood. The hare’s eyes settled, its breath gentled. Elias stroked its ears until it trembled only a little and then sprang, anxious, slick-bellied, into the hedge. “And it’s not iron that calls me,” he added. “It’s work.”

Quill transferred from shoulder to satchel with a spring and a flap. He was lean as a one-word answer and striped like a half-remembered song. “It will be a day for it,” the cat said, staring down the lane as if he could see what the thickening morning mist was trying to hide. “People are telling stories. I’ve counted three already getting born in the last ten minutes. Two without fathers.”

“Stories breed,” Elias said, wiping his hands on his coat. The coat had seen better days. It had seen days it would never speak of to anyone. He straightened and squinted toward High Street. “Let’s see who needs a broom.”

The butcher’s window, when they reached it, looked as if it had been shut in on a thundercloud. Fat words and bruised smears had unrolled from the top sash and pooled against the slate. The usual neat row of fleck-white rabbits, pink trotters, parcels tied with string and bald knuckles of beef had disappeared behind a blackened gloss. When Elias put his face to the glass to peer through, the words smeared there clung to his breath and shivered like fish under ice.

“Do you mind,” Mrs. Hardesty snapped, appearing at his elbow with a wiping cloth as if she meant to scour his cheek. “I’ve enough trouble with this muck without your steaming it. And don’t you come near my sausages.”

“I wasn’t planning to,” Elias said. He stood back and bowed a little—old habit; he’d grown up with the Hardestys’ shouts in his ear and their butcher’s paper under his nose. “May I look?”

Mrs. Hardesty sniffed. Her cap was crooked and the color in her cheeks had been painted there by fury. “You’ll do more than look or I’ll have you—what do wizards get? Fined? Hanged?”

“Tea,” Elias said thoughtfully. “Or a biscuit, if the work’s hard.” He put his hand flat upon the glass. The words under his palm quivered. They had weight and grain to them, the oily insistence of ink left long enough to dry into the skin. He could make out letters now that the light was coming up: liar, fiend, children, from the blood. Andover made a low sound in his ear then, old brick and chalk and pig-iron, the faint groan of rope over a pulley. His town had a voice if you listened and didn’t tell anyone you could. It sounded weary and short-tempered before breakfast. A man clearing his throat and not much more.

Quill leaped neatly onto the window frame and put one paw into the ink. He drew it out again quickly, shaking off glossy drops. “Pfft,” he said. “That’s not from ink. Or it is, but not the sort from your little bottles. That’s printed malice. Binding. You smell it?”

Elias did. Under the butcher’s familiar tang—the iron of blood, the sweet rot of fat and aging sawdust—there was the sharp naphthalene-apple stink of new pamphlets. He took his hand from the window and the letters slopped against the place his palm had been, trying not to let go, but his touch had been light and he knew how to slip politely from a trouble. He turned to Mrs. Hardesty. “Who did you call first? The church? Constable?”

“I called nobody,” she said, and then flicked a glance to the line of waiting people behind him. The line, which had been very still and unwilling to meet Elias’s eye, shifted. “Well. I sent my Willy for the vicar. Willy hasn’t been back. It’s your mess. You did it. It says so right there.” She jabbed her cloth at the words.

“Does it,” Elias murmured. He put his head close to the glass again until his own face appeared behind the ink as a gray ghost. He saw the letters more clearly now. Their edges were not ragged like spilled ink should be; they were crisp, set like type. The words slid when he looked, trying to be something else: slaughterer, corruptor, worm in the belly of the town. He had the sensation of the window speaking to him but not with its own tongue. A man’s voice, soft and amused, licking at the syllables as they turned round.

“I’ve seen this work,” he said. “Once. Far east of here. In a little place whose name I don’t intend to remember.” He glanced at Quill. “Are there any prints?”

“Which sort?” Quill’s ears were flat. “Foot or thumb?”

“Feather,” Elias said. He shook his head as if to clear it of the voice, though it had already gone, sliding away into the wet like a rat. “Look for a crow’s-foot. Corner, if it’s properly done.”

The cat slunk along the sill, careful not to let any more of the black touch him, and peered at the meeting of glass and wood. He sniffed, sneezed, lifted a whisker the way he lifted a sword when a mouse needed its pride pricked. “There,” he said. “In the left lower corner. Three scratches and a dot. Like someone signed with a bird.”

Elias felt the town shiver under his boots, a thud down the length of the street as if the bell had rung but only inside people’s bones. He curled his fingers and wanted a mug in them, wanted heat. “We’ll pull this down,” he said, raising his voice so the line could hear and not hear. “It won’t break the glass. No one will smash anything. This is only ink trying to be a story.”

“It is a story,” muttered a man behind him. He had the look of a man who had been told something shocking in the dark and had had to walk home with his hands in his pockets and the shocking thing like a lantern in his mouth. “Said you did a thing with old Mr. Crisp’s daughter. Said you—” His voice ran out and his face went pink. “Sorry, Elias. I shouldn’t. It’s… it says it.”

“It’s not true,” Elias said. He didn’t say it sharply. You couldn’t beat a story by shouting at it. He breathed out, and his breath made the black crawl again, and he spoke a word you would not find in a book because it wasn’t written anywhere. It belonged to Andover and to the chalk under Andover and to the old law of a place that would not be humiliated by paper. It was a word that woke a broommaid in a cottage kitchen at the edge of town, ten miles from there, and made her think suddenly to scrub the hearth. It made a boy remember he had forgotten to shut the gate on the sheep. It made the dog turn thrice and lie down on the right side of the rug. It was a word of tidying up.

The ink flinched.

“Again,” Quill murmured.

Elias said the word again, softer. He felt it go out, like a rill of water down a slight slope, into the gutters and the wells. The ink drew back from his hand as if it didn’t want to be touched by something so dull and domestic. “Sweep,” he said, and “set to rights,” and “enough,” and the butcher’s wife shuddered, and the boy at the end of the line started to cry without knowing why, and the window cleared as if someone were rolling up a blind. Ink gathered itself reluctantly into the corners and became a clotted spider, which skittered off into the morning.

“Don’t worry about that,” Elias told Mrs. Hardesty as she flinched. “It doesn’t bite anything with a backbone.” He was lying but he expected the spider would like best to disappear in a drain and mope.

The line exhaled. People came briskly to life with the shock of relief that was almost anger. “If there’s any of it on my sausages—” Mrs. Hardesty began, but the words died away; she was looking at Elias as if she had never seen him before. “Who would do such a thing?” she said softly. “To my window? To our town?”

“Someone poor in stories,” Quill answered. He was twisting his paw delicately, wiping it on the lapel of Elias’s coat with exact malice. “Someone who only has the kind that rot from the inside.”

Elias rubbed the back of his neck where the hairs had stiffened. The word he had said was still going about its business. You didn’t want to overdo a thing like that or the town would be too tidy to bear. He looked up and down High Street. Every doorway had collected a listener. Faces like clocks with two fingers pointing different ways. He felt the weight of his own name on these people’s tongues and it made a private ache down the center of his sternum, as if someone had pressed a thumb there and had not taken it away.

“It’s a mark,” he said carefully. “A dare. If you see anything like that—” He flicked a look. The three scratches and a dot were gone. He had expected that. “—you’ll tell me. Don’t read it. Or if you must read it, don’t believe it. It’s like walking over river ice: you can, but you’ll come home wet and cold and it was only foolishness.”

“Who?” someone asked. “Who is it?” And the repetition came like sparrows from the eaves: who, who, who. Andover was not a small town but it could make itself small when it felt afraid.

Elias did not say a name, not because he did not have one in his mouth but because some names liked the air too much. He nodded to Mrs. Hardesty, and she nodded back, and the world made a tiny clack as a cog took a tooth. Work to do. Sausages to sell. People began to talk at once, and Quill leaped down and trotted before Elias like a banner.

They turned the corner into Scanner’s Yard and found a pamphlet tied to Elias’s blue door with string.

It looked as if the hedgerows had shed a skin in the night and someone had gathered it and made something flat of it and beaten it with the truth until it forgot the wild. It had sprigs along the margin like the small weeds that grow in paper, not because someone drew them but because the plant had not been entirely convinced it was dead. The title was in thick black, and it smiled at him with every tooth.

The Sorcerer of Andover Eats Children.

“Does he,” said Elias. His voice did not shake. He untied the string and held the pamphlet like a fish that he intended to return to the water unhurt. He opened it. The smell of it came off the pages in a sick-sweet breath.

“Don’t,” Quill said sharply. “There’s a burr inside. It’s set to catch.”

“I see it,” Elias murmured. “Hold your tongue. If I miss it, tell me which way I bled.” He thewed through the first paragraph with the kind of attention he would give to a ditch in darkness. The sentences were almost right. Almost true. He had—for instance—lived here since he was six, and yes, Mrs. Coppin had given him bread on Thursdays, and yes, he had once chased a badger out of a cellar with a broom. But the badger had not spoken to him with Mr. Crisp’s daughter’s voice and he had not—and here the words turned like a worm in a hand—worn a mask made from the skin of a child. The pamphlet was a map of a place that was Andover and not, with streets that led where they should but came out into rooms that smelled of pigs when they should have smelled of clean bed linen. It was the kind of story that crawled you and left little grit trails behind your eyes.

“Enough,” Quill said. “He’s signed it in the colophon. Look.”

Elias turned to the last page. The mark was there in the tiny print, three scratches and a dot, and also the name. It wasn’t a true name. Wizards had those, some of them kept in folded paper under the mattress of someone they trusted. It was a name chosen and worn in daylight. Vellum Crowe.

“Well,” Elias said. His coffee he’d meant to go home and make had gone suddenly very necessary and very far away. He looked up and saw across the Yard the face of Hester Stowe in her window, chin tucked in the heel of her hand, watching. Hester had been eight the last time the river overran the bank and had followed Elias stoutly in bare feet while he spoke to the Anton and told it it was not time yet. He smiled at her in the ordinary way and she gave him an ordinary smile back. The ordinary had become very dear in an instant.

“What do you do?” Quill asked. He was too quiet. He was never quiet when he was frightened. It was his vanity; he believed fear made him stupid and he hated that.

“Tea,” Elias said automatically. “Biscuits. We promised Mrs. Coppin to look at her chimney after dinner.”

“That order makes no sense,” Quill said, relieved to be cross. “Milk first.”

“It does,” Elias said. “It does enough. Do you know why he sent this to my door?” He took in a breath of the smell of the pamphlet and let it go. He could see the burr quivering in it, set like a nettle almost under the skin of the words. He folded it carefully and set it on the sill. It would not go off yet. “He wants me to come to him. He’ll lay down a trail of hurt and filth until I do. He likes the walk better than the meeting.”

“Then don’t go,” Quill said at once. “Sit. Roll yourself up in a blanket. Let me bite anyone who knocks.”

“I’m not made for the hearth,” Elias said, but not unkindly. He pushed open the door and they went in. The house smelled of sage and floor wax. There were small bags hung on the pegs by the door—sprigs of lavender, a twist of iron filings, a length of plaited hair he didn’t remember making but he knew he had. He set water to boil and put bread on a plate and two lumps of sugar because sometimes, after a blow, there was nothing else to be done that would not make it worse. He held his hands to the kettle and watched the steam rise up in muslin threads. He said, to the steam, “He was waiting, this one. Somewhere damp. Somewhere people don’t go because they get lonely if they do.”

“Under the viaduct,” Quill suggested.

“Not… west of us. Not the water meadows. He smells of ink gone moldy. That’s a room whose window never opens. Basement. Or a house shuttered long.”

“You know him?”

“I know his kind.” Elias poured the water over the tea. The smell rose up, golden and brown. He had known many kinds. There were wizards who moved stones with their voices and wizards who took happiness like the top of a soft-boiled egg. Some of them you could talk with. Some you could outlast. There were the wicked and the sad and very many who were both. A man who made up nasty stories about his enemies because he liked to see how the town would turn—he was not the worst. But he was not small either. Nasty stories ate. “He’ll come for more than my window,” Elias said.

“He came for your name,” Quill said, and then he started, because something hit the door. Not the door exactly. The air by the door. A soft slapping, like wetted paper thrown at varnish.

Elias set down his tea. He did not sigh. He took up his penknife, which had never been nervous about being only a penknife, and went to open the door.

A patch of blackness the size of a dinner plate lurched off the jamb and fluttered at him, all corners. It was not a bird but it wanted to be. It wanted very badly to be. It came at his eyes. He stepped neatly to the side. Quill, who had no intention of letting a piece of ink peck his master to blindness, did something he was not proud of later: he jumped into the air shoulder first and caught the thing. It squealed. The squeal was human, high and pleased in its own pain, and it made Elias’s stomach turn over. He flicked the knife and the thing tore open and fell to the step and lay there shuddering like a heart. It was letters. It was made of words.

“Bother,” Elias said, because the little boy across the Yard had appeared in his doorway with his mother’s apron tied round his middle, and Elias had borrowed Bother from that house for so long it had become his. “He’ll send more of those if we let him think it works.”

Quill spit a letter out of his mouth. It wriggled and went flat and climbed the doorjamb like a bug. “Let him,” the cat said darkly, and then coughed. “Apologies. It had an e lodged at the back of my throat. Stupid letter.”

“Take the other door,” Elias said to the letters on the step because it amused him to act as if he wasn’t bothered. He went back inside, shut the door gently and leaned against it. His hands were steady. There were a thousand things to do and every one of them small. He could not go to the basement where Vellum Crowe waited—if it was a basement—with his coat smelling of Hardesty’s shop and his tea growing cold. The answer to a sorcery like this was never a loud one. It was a washing line and a point at its center with a peg.

“Who told you?” Quill asked a minute later when they had their tea and their bread and they sat on the back step looking over the small garden. “That you’d be the kind of person who cleaned this sort of mess.”

“You did,” Elias said. “When you followed me home from the mill and refused to come in because the doormat said Wipe Your Feet as if it had been drawn by a bully.”

Quill sniffed. “I was a kitten. I thought all rugs were orders.”

“You do still,” Elias said, and that made Quill smile, which he did with his whiskers. “Also, my mother. Not with words. She scrubbed the lie out of everything with her day. She applied water and a certain song to it. My father—” He stopped. His father had been less of a shape. A pair of boots by the door. A laugh that could be felt through the floorboards if it was a good laugh, if it was in season.

“Eat,” Quill commanded, and Elias did. They finished tea and washed the cups. By then the Yard had emptied into the day, and the sun slid its greasy hair out of its cap and the mist began to burn away. People came by in twos and threes to ask if Elias needed anything and to not look at the pamphlet on the sill. He told them no and thank you and—always—the same thing: if words appear where they should not, call me, do not read them, it will make you ill.

Midday brought Hester Stowe to his door with a handkerchief tied to a stick. “I’m going to beat my brother with it,” she announced, pushing past him into the kitchen. “He said you ate a child because you were hungry. I told him you eat scones and he said you put glue in the jam so you could catch a fly in it. He said you stole Mr. Crisp’s—” She stopped, seeing the pamphlet, and her mouth went O.

Elias took the handkerchief from her gently and untied the knot. Inside was a frog and two copper coins. “I don’t accept frogs as payment,” he said solemnly. “They hop out of my pocket.”

“I know,” Hester said, and blinked hard. Her eyes had begun to fill because she had read the word eats and the word children and there was the burr under the skin of the sentence and her body had felt it, not her mind. “Elias,” she whispered, and the whisper had in it exactly enough trust to tear a man in two.

“I’m all right,” he said, crouching to be at her height. He always forgot how little most people were, and how tall he had become without meaning to. “Is your brother all right?”

“He’s stupid. He has scabs all over his knees and none in his head.”

“Good,” Elias said. “Scabs on knees mean there’s still some honesty in him.” He looked at Quill. “Would you like to show Hester something?”

“No,” Quill said at once. He did not care for performing. But Hester’s tear had fallen and stuck at the corner of her mouth like a bead and Quill could not bear beads on children, and so he sat up very straight and looked at the frog. “I will require the frog,” he said.

Hester presented it. Quill observed it gravely. “Miss Frog,” he said, “you are safe. And unspectacular. Leap once if this is true, twice if it is not.” The frog leaped once. Quill nodded. “Now. Hester. Leap once if what your brother said is confusing your guts. Twice if it is not.”

Hester leaped once without smiling. Then she realized what she’d done and tried very hard not to make a face. Quill flicked an ear. “Now listen to this: Elias and I will not eat you. Not past, not present, not future. Not in books, not in alleys, not in soups. Is any of that false?”

Hester held her breath and sipped at the words as if they might be hot. “No.”

“Then tell your stupid brother we’ll eat him instead,” Quill said sweetly, and Elias sighed and Hester laughed and the burr he had seen under the pamphlet’s skin came unseated, just a little, and scrabbled and fell away.

When Hester had gone, Elias made himself read the pamphlet through to the end. It took an hour. It left a taste like pennies in his mouth for the rest of the day. He followed the stitch-work of the lies and saw the hands that had made them. Not many hands. One careful pair. They had chosen words as if choosing herbs for a medicine that would make the town’s blood thin. They had saved a particular spice for last: at the bottom of the last page, in tiny, fine type that required the angle of a midwife’s gaze to see, was a line that even Quill had missed: It is not safe to look him in the eyes.

“You clever coward,” Elias said aloud. “You will want them to look down when they see me.” He put the pamphlet in a drawer, knowing it would shimmy out and follow him when it liked because this was not over. He washed his hands. He finished his work—Mrs. Coppin’s chimney had a bat in it; he told it kindly to move to the eaves; it did—and he let the day go on being a day while somewhere, he knew, Vellum Crowe was making another day into something not entirely itself.

He dreamt of crows that night. Of course he did. He lay under a sky the exact slate color of the butcher’s window at its worst and watched a flock of black paper tearing itself into pieces and reassembling as a different bird every time. One was a swallow with a stick for a belly. One was a gull with a nail through its head, which bothered it not at all. When he woke, Quill was asleep with his face in Elias’s ear as if he could pour dreams out like water and drink them. Elias lay there quietly because the house was listening, and then set his feet to the floor like a man stepping into a cold stream.

The morning, which had thought it was going to be ordinary, changed its mind when the second pamphlet arrived and went directly for Mrs. Troon’s baby. Mrs. Troon had been carrying the baby down the slope to the water when a wind rose and flapped at the paper in her apron pocket. She had taken it out and read two lines before she remembered Elias had told her not to. Later she would not be able to recall setting the baby down. She would say she dropped her shawl and the shawl cried, and when she looked up the child sat by the edge of the river with a woman’s face on, a sour-faced woman with a mouth like a knife mark, who was telling the child in a voice thinner than tin that a narrow thing was the same as a safe thing. The child began to scoot without quite crawling toward the water.

Hester Stowe, truant and proud of it, was the one who screamed.

By the time Elias reached the bank, breath ragged, the child had one foot wet, one foot dry, and was peering at his own reflection as if he had a secret. The river was gray and earnest. The pamphlet lay on the grass with its throat open, letting out a smell like pith. Elias scooped the child up and the reflection shrugged and took one of those steps you sometimes see on a ladder when you climb above the roofline and don’t expect it. Elias held the child tight and spoke to the river without raising his voice. He called it by its little name, which the Anton wore only when it turned under Andover Bridge and looked up at the sky for a moment as if it was going to decide whether to go on. “You’ve misread your orders,” he said. “The fetch is not for today.”

The river settled like a big animal deciding not to ask for dinner just yet. The child hiccuped and put his wet foot on Elias’s knee. The sour-faced woman stepped, briefly, onto a stone and then became the stone and then did not exist as a separate thing anymore.

“Now,” Elias said to Mrs. Troon, very gentle because her face had shattered and was in several places at once. “Go home. Remember that the baby was born on a Tuesday. Tuesdays have cleverness. You will need to keep an eye on that.” Mrs. Troon nodded and bobbled the child and went away holding him as if he would otherwise join the boys on the bridge and smoke.

Hester went to pick up the pamphlet. Elias stopped her with a glance and a word. She froze. Quill, who had arrived late and furious and still beautiful, paced round the paper with his back arched, making a sound like a kettle at the boil.

“Don’t dramatize,” Elias said absentmindedly. He put his penknife into his teeth and unfurled the pamphlet carefully with his fingertips so that not a whisper brushed him. The title was worse, if you could call that possible. The Sorcerer of Andover Whispers In Rivers, Do Not Let Your Children Sleep. “Original,” Elias muttered. He pulled a thread from his cuff, a long one; he had been saving it without noticing, and laid it along the seam. The thread was home and will and bread and crumbs and crumbs again. It lay down and went to sleep. The pamphlet did not like that. It twitched and tried to be interesting. The thread was not; it continued to be home. The pamphlet gave up its right to be the most interesting thing on the grass and sighed and lay still.

“Get a box,” Elias said. “Something with corners. Mrs. Coppin’s old biscuit tin. The one with the lid that sticks.”

They put the pamphlet in the tin and the tin on the shelf and the shelf under a chair and the chair in front of the door. It was not proper wizard work. It was a grandmother’s work. It turned out to be the right kind.

The town wrinkled itself all afternoon like a face misfitted. It could not settle. People stopped in the street to shake their heads as if to fling water from their ears. Mr. Crisp’s daughter—who was not the least bit inclined to speak with anyone about anything that was not a real thing in front of her face—crossed to Elias where he was standing by the green and stuck out her hand as if she were shaking his name. “They can’t take what they haven’t got,” she said. “Here.” She pressed something into his palm. It was a small painted wooden soldier with the paint rubbed off its nose. It had been sad for so long it had become happy again by accident.

“I can use that,” Elias said seriously. He watched her shoulder as she went away and thought about how people made themselves. You learned to wipe your own feet.

By dusk, the third attack came, and it came not as paper but as people. Four of them, men he knew well enough to borrow a spade from. Their faces had been scuffed. The pamphlets had taken two fingers and a corner off their names and the men hadn’t noticed. They came with their hats off, which was politeness, and with sticks, which was not.

“Elias,” the first man said. His name was Tom but the pamphlet had made it Ton and he had not felt the subtraction. “We’ve been asked to speak to you on the town’s behalf.”

“Who asked you?” Elias said. He stood in his doorway with Quill winding round his ankles like rope.

The men frowned faintly, as if the question were rude. Tom—Ton—worried his stick. “The truth,” he said. “You shouldn’t look us in the eyes.”

“I don’t have to,” Elias said. He looked at their hands instead. One of them had a blister where a pen had been held too tight. One had coal dust at the nail. One had a ring that fit too loose. He wanted very badly to send them home to their wives. He did not want to humiliate them. He said, “You’ve been fed something that doesn’t agree with you. I have a medicine for that. It tastes like tea.”

The men listened to the word tea with visible relief. It had the right number of vowels. Ton took a breath and then looked furious at himself, as if he had done some small thing extremely well in front of the wrong person. “We’re not fools,” he said. “We didn’t read that—” He stopped because he had, he had read it twice, once for himself and once for a version of himself with his thumb in his mouth.

“I know,” Elias said. He opened the door wider. “Come in. You can lean the sticks by the stove. It doesn’t mind sticks.” He let them pass because he was Andover and they were Andover and there was a sort of magic in that which had nothing of wands and light in it. He gave them tea. He told them the story of a fish that had swallowed a ring and then spat it up in a puddle and how the ring had rolled to the door of a woman who had been looking for a sign. He told it badly. They listened and sipped and some of the nasty story in them sloughed away because ordinary stories had teeth too.

“What are we going to do,” Ton said at last, eyes on his cup. “If there are papers in the street saying we are the sort who cannot tell?”

“We will be the sort who can,” Elias said. “And we will be the sort who keep going to the shop for bread with our heads up. There will be more of it before there is less. Bring me anything a crow has scratched.”

“And you,” Ton said, eyes lifting just enough. “What will you do?”

“I will make up a story of my own,” Elias said. “It will be slow, because it will be true. But it will go through your house and not break a cup. It will remind you where you put your boots. It will sit at the foot of your bed in the night and when you wake, it will be gone and you will keep the shape of it.” He smiled. “Also, I will find him. Ink doesn’t keep a man.” He held up the painted soldier. “He’s north of here.”

“Why,” Quill muttered, “do you always say north as if it’s an ache in your left shoulder.”

“Because that’s where the ache is,” Elias said.

The men went home politely and did not leave their sticks. They had forgotten them. Elias set the sticks against the wall where they wouldn’t trip anyone and closed the door and leaned his head against it. He did not open the drawer where the pamphlet lay. He did not throw up. He was not a hero when he was most useful; he was only himself and there were days when that had to be enough.

“He wants you outside the town,” Quill said. “He wants you somewhere he can say is not you, not yours.”

“He wants me in a room with no window and a floor you can wash until the boards wear through,” Elias said. His voice did an odd thing then. It sounded like his father’s when his father remembered a song halfway through the second verse and the song forgot him back. “I will go where he wants,” he added softly. “But not like that. And not yet.”

He did not sleep much that night. Andover did, though; it lay down and wore its winter face and snored. The town dreamed of a harvest that had already been brought in and a storm that would not break the thatch. It dreamed no dreams with letters in.

The morning made a joke of being fine. A sky as clear as water held up the houses. Elias set his hand on the bricks of his doorway and felt the place purr. He took a small bag, the painted soldier, three lengths of string, his penknife and a biscuit he had not earned. Quill jumped into the bag and then out again and decided to go without the indignity.

“Where,” Quill said. “Say you. Say it with your mouth.”

“We will start at the bookbinder’s,” Elias said. “Magdalene Plum saw a mark like that once. She won’t tell me she did. She will tell me she did not not. Then we will go north. Not far. Not fast. We will step from harmless to less harmless to unkind to cruel. We will keep stepping. We will set ourselves on the ground like a fact.”

“Like a pebble you can’t get out of your shoe,” Quill said approvingly. He waved his tail at the door as if it were an audience. “Back soon,” he told the lintel. “Or not.”

Magdalene Plum’s shop was not a shop so much as a long sigh with shelves in it. Paper lived here. It did not have to strain to keep still; Magdalene had a way of telling it to behave just with her throat. She looked up when Elias came in. She had the kind of face that had never been ungenerous and never would be. “I will not mend a slander,” she said without greeting.

“I’m not asking you to,” Elias said. He put down the painted soldier and then took it up again because it had become dearer to him every time it crossed air. “I need the smell.”

Magdalene’s nostrils flared delicately, as if she had just been offered something she could not tell at a glance was a treat or a trap. “It’s the same. Worse paper. Cheaper ink. Sign of a man who chooses cost over comfort because he thinks the discomfort proves his seriousness.”

“Yes,” Elias said. “Also he has a scar.”

“We all have scars.” Magdalene’s eyes were dark as mischief. “I suppose you want me to tell you where it was made. I suppose you want it brought to hand like a cake.”

“Not cake,” Elias said. “Bread.”

“Hm,” she said, because she recognized the spell he was asking for and objected to it on principle. “It’s below the school. In the old rooms where they kept the maps and the poor noise. The paper came up the road with a man who ought not have walked it. He wore his boots thin trying to keep quiet. He had a crow. It isn’t really a crow. It’s the habit of a crow—the bit that loves bright, hateful bits—and he feeds it pins.”

“Thank you,” Elias said, meaning it twice. “Do you know him?”

“I know what he reads,” Magdalene said. “He reads instructions on how to be important.” She bent to pick up a book and spoke to it as if it had whistled at her. “He reads lists. Mostly he reads the shape of his own mouth. Go with care. Do not let him make you into a litany. He will put numbers on you if he can.” She lifted her head and the softness was gone. “If you come back with less of your name I will keep the remainder safe for you,” she said. “Even if it is only the dot.”

“Keep the dot,” Elias said. “That’s the piece men miss. Thank you.”

Outside, the street was bent in the shape of an arrow pointing north. It had always been bent that way. Elias had not always been willing to see it. He and Quill walked the length of it and no one stopped them. The town loomed behind and then merely stood there, its little windows looking into its little rooms, making soup of its life. The school on the northern edge had been a scandal when it was next to new; the builders had run off with the money and the roof was wrong and the boys had learned to recite multiplication tables exactly loudly enough to drown the drip in the back corridor. Elias and Quill went round to the side where the slate fell green and the moss kept house on the steps.

The door to the lower rooms was kept with a slat and a promise. Elias unhooked both. The air that breathed out at him was tidy and wrong, as if someone had put all the chairs on the tables and called it truth.

“You should call him out,” Quill said. “You should knock and say Come taste your own mouth. You should make him eat it.”

“I should make him come to my kitchen,” Elias said. “The sky, it turns out, is mine. The water. The inside of my house. Not this. Not yet.”

They went down the steps. One of the bulbs had burnt out and the others made a noise like a furious fly. The air smelled of wet string and school soups. Elias felt the first thread of Vellum Crowe’s presence like a glove. It slid across his knuckles and then he was wearing it whether he wished or not.

A door stood ajar. Ink lay on the floor in a skin. Someone had tried to leave and had not. Elias stepped carefully around a dark oval that was not a bucket and not a shadow. Quill’s fur stood up in a stripe. “He sees us,” he said.

“I know,” Elias said. “Let him. He’s watching from nowhere. This is no one’s house. He has not fed it. It will not keep him.”

“Elias Fiske,” said a voice. It was a thin voice taught to be wide. It came from the next room and from the ceiling and from inside the frame of a fake map that had never been a country. It had a smile wrapped up in it for later use. “Andover’s broom. Andover’s boy. Did you like the joke about the window? It made them look at themselves. It made them very clean.”

“I am not a boy,” Elias said, because it was an inexplicable point of pride with him and always had been. “You’re Vellum Crowe. Or whatever your mother calls you when you’ve been unkind to your dinner.”

Something moved in the corner of the room, a shadow picking at its nails. “My mother,” the voice said thoughtfully. “I do not remember what she called me. People remember that sort of thing. I only remember that I was told not to point because I would call things and then what would we do. But here we are. I pointed. What will we do.”

“We,” Elias said, entering the room and then stopping because he knew a trap when he felt one, “will sit. You can stand. It’s your mess.” He stood anyway. The room had no chairs; they had been turned into what chairs are when they forget: splinters and rudeness. A press squatted in the corner, proud of its iron. Its handle gleamed from liking hands and the idea of hands. On the wall hung letters cut out of paper and pinned on with steel. The floor had the grit of tears.

“You think words are air,” Vellum Crowe said, and Elias heard the way he said words, the s in it like a bit of broken glass. “You think they will sweep if you tell them to because you are a whispering man. Boys who whisper at rivers. Little ones.”

“I think words are the floors we stand on,” Elias said. “And the roofs that keep us from getting wet. And the bowls we put soup in. And the names of our daughters in our mouths when we are ill. They are not toys and they are not pins and they are not what you think they are when you stay below the sky.”

The silence that followed had in it the exact sound of Vellum Crowe glancing at the ceiling and failing to remember what color sky might be. “You will lose your town,” he said lightly. “They will eat you and not because they are hungry. Only because it is something to do.” He moved then and stepped into himself and there he was: a narrow man, more colorless than pale, with ink at his cuffs and a ring of powder at his collarbone where he had patted himself to keep from shining with sweat. His hair had tried to be black and had given up. He had chosen his nose as if picking one from a jar, not considering whether it would suit him. His mouth was not the kind you would lend a cup to. He smiled. “It is already happening,” he said.

“You sign your papers with a crow’s foot,” Elias said.

“I sign the parts of people that think they’re resistant,” Vellum said. “I make space. I make room between mouths and brains. I give time for people to see their own ideas come walking. Have you never wanted that?”

Elias thought of a day ten years ago when he had stood on the bridge and wanted the river to swallow a man who had said his mother had… he shut the thought away with a shuffle, as you would tuck in a sheet. “No,” he said. “Not enough to put my face in it. You do not smell like a basement. You smell like an attic. Did your mother send you up there? Sit with the wasps and old hats. Make up names for them. Come down with a bent back.”

“You will tell me a story to make me into a person people don’t hate,” Vellum said. He leaned sideways and a row of letters leaned with him, charmed. “Everyone thinks he’s a mother. Even cats.”

“I will tell you one,” Elias said, and he felt Quill prick his ankle with one needle of claw: be careful, old man. “Slowly. Later. For now, I will take back what you put in my town. I will pour water on it and let it swell and swell and turn back into pulp and plant and dirt.”

“You will never take it all,” Vellum said, and his mouth did something that wanted to be a chuckle and became a cough. “They will always remember a part. The bad part. People keep those. They polish with them.”

“I know,” Elias said, and the knowledge lay heavy and honest between them. “Yes. But I will mend and mend. That is my magic. Yours is to break and be entertained. Mine is to feel my hands hurt.”

Vellum’s eyes—he had gray eyes, ink washed with rain—narrowed. “We are not so different. I do not break. I write. The town breaks itself on the reading.”

“That’s worse,” Quill said. He had kept still until now. He put his tail high and walked over the floor with terrible daintiness as if he were in another place where there were flowers worth not stepping on. “Elias,” he said, “this smells like a story where the first chapter is someone in a cellar telling themselves they’re right.”

“It does,” Elias said. He took out the painted soldier and set it on the press. Vellum’s gaze caught on it. A little startled heat rose in his cheeks, a child caught taking apples. Elias did not know what it meant but he knew it well enough to tuck away. “This is the bit where I tell you what I need. I need you to stop sending paper into the rooms of children. I need you to keep my name out of your mouth.”

“You cannot take the food from me,” Vellum said. “I eat this.”

“We will give you soup,” Quill offered, deadpan. “Bread and soup. A blanket.”

“Be careful,” Vellum said, and now the glass-forward sneer was gone. In its place was something like warning. “I have a picture of you in my pocket in which you are crying. If I let it out—”

“You’ll make me cry,” Elias said. “Yes. And then what. You’ll send a paper around to tell them I cried? They will not mind. They keep vegetables in the cool. I am a man with a hearth. You cannot win that way.”

Vellum straightened and the room tightened, as if someone had pulled the cloth of it inward and tied a knot in the middle. He moved his fingers and the letters on the wall pulled themselves off and came like moths, a cloud of barbed edges. They whispered as they came. One of them said liar in Elias’s left ear and one of them said fiend in his right and one of them climbed the side of his neck to tell him for certain of Mrs. Troon’s baby meeting its end by noon without his meddling. He could feel the burrs; he closed his eyes because he would not give them the color of them.

Quill leaped. He was small but you do not have to be large to interfere. He went mouth-open at the letter called fiend and swallowed it with an ugly gulp and spat it out into a corner, where it lay twitching like a centipede. Elias, eyes still shut, reached out and said the word he had said to the window. He said it three times, the last time almost without sound, and the letters lost interest in the thought they had been given and fluttered aimlessly in the beam of the buzzing lights. Vellum hissed between his teeth.

“Housework,” he said contemptuously. “You sweep. You make dust. You are a small man with a broom. You believe if you tidy enough you will not think about the two days your mother did not come home.”

Elias opened his eyes and looked at him and the hurt in the center of him burned a color Vellum would not have a word for if he had all the pamphlets in the world. “Yes,” he said. “And yet we will see.”

“Go back,” Vellum said, suddenly sharp, as if he had pricked his own finger on his own pin. “Go back and wait. I have not finished deciding what to call you. If I name you right you will be kindling.”

“I won’t be,” Elias said, and then, because he had been taught not to leave a room without taking something from it to keep it from coming after you, he took a small thing: the dot. The dot at the end of a sentence pinned above the press, forgotten, humble, necessary. He put it in his pocket and felt it settle there like a stone and like a seed. He turned and went out.

On the steps, north falling away ahead like a question, the sky showing its throat, Quill shook himself hard. Tiny flecks of black came off his whiskers. “He pricked you,” the cat said.

“He did,” Elias said. His voice did not shake. It would later. “He knows where to push. He’s had practice.”

“North,” Quill said, peering up out of his own head at the new place where the ache had shifted to. “Not always north.”

“No,” Elias said. He put his hand in his pocket and touched the period. It was warm. It was ridiculous. It was the end of a sentence without its sentence. It made him smile. “We’ll go where he thinks we won’t. And we’ll go with both hands. Andover is not a small thing. It is a weight in my mouth. He can go on making nasty stories until his fingers bleed. I’ll learn the bigger ones.”

They stood there until the bell in the church stepped a chime into the town and the sound went up and came down again, and Elias and his cat set their feet toward home. The town breathed them in and did not choke. The air, for once, said nothing about children in soups. Hester Stowe ran past them with her hair uncombed and did not look away. She waved. She shouted over her shoulder, clear as brass, “My brother says you made him feel silly. I told him he needed the practice.” Elias waved and the dot in his pocket beat once against his fingers like a heart. He looked at the sky and saw a shape in it that might have been a crow, might have been a piece of scrap blown up and up.

“Let him tell it,” he said aloud, to the sky, to the town. “We’ll tell a better one.” The day went on and the smell of a bakery came along the street and he told his feet to keep in time with it and not with the voice in his memory saying, do not look them in the eye. He looked everyone in the eye. If it stung, well, tea would help.

That night he read no pamphlets. He took out the biscuit tin and laid the second one on top of the first, and set a book on them and a stone he had brought home from the river and then his hand, as if blessing bread. Quill slept with his back jammed against Elias’s chest, guarding with his spine. Andover snored again. Somewhere in the rooms below the school a man went on telling himself that the story was the same as the person, that if you got the word right you would own the thing. He would find out otherwise. It would not happen quickly. But it would. And when the morning came, Elias would rise and wash his face and go to buy sausages and pick up a letter from Magdalene Plum. It would say, in her prim hand, three scratches and a dot. It would say: we are not brittle. It would say the thing he needed and the thing he already knew, which was that a line can be drawn under anything, and under that line might be written a better thought. He would take up his broom and his penknife and his cat. He would go on. The hero of Andover does not glow. He stands. He goes back for the small, fallen, required. He knows—which is a kind of magic, too—that you cannot win a town with ink. You win it by living in it long enough to know where the tea is kept. He meant to live long enough. And longer, if he could be rude about it.

The next morning began with flour on the air. Saturday had arrived with its hands full. Bread rose in ovens and people in beds and a pale sun put its shoulder to the roofs and shoved. Elias had the habit of taking Saturday by the polite scruff and showing it where to stand. He swept his step, because it was neighborly, and returned Mrs. Troon’s handkerchief washed and pressed, because she would see the pressing and believe in the washing. He found three pebbles in his pocket that he did not remember collecting and set them on the sill to see if they had any intention in them. One did; it wanted to be part of a ring. He left it to think the rest through.

Quill, who had no patience with pebbles, was stalking the mild, important fly that lived in the kitchen and had learned the shape of a cat’s paw and the sound of a shout. “It will die in a week,” Quill said, sitting down suddenly as if overcome by mercy. “Or of boredom. It visits only three corners. It is a fly with a limited imagination.”

“It is a fly who knows what it is about,” Elias said. He tied his scarf without looking and it came out even. Evenness on a Saturday was a spell all its own. “We’re going to Magdalene’s,” he added. “And then to the green.”

Quill’s ears twitched. “We are taking books to the grass? They don’t like it. Grass goes between the pages and then you hear whispering when you open to find a recipe.”

“Not books,” Elias said. “Boards.”

Magdalene Plum had said no three times before she said yes, and she had done it with her eyebrows and an intake of breath and a lean away and finally with her mouth. “You will not print an argument,” she said as if it were a swear. “You will not print a defense. You will not print the words not and true on the same line.”

“No,” Elias said. “Shopping lists.”

She stared at him. “You are a tiresome man.”

“Nevertheless,” Elias said, and his smile did not work on Magdalene because she had known him since he was a boy and had watched him call a lost kitten out of a coal scuttle and then ask it to return the coal. “Blank shopping lists,” he clarified. “Name at the top. Little lines below, with nothing on them. And a place at the bottom for a note to oneself.”

Magdalene made the sound of a woman considering both treason and tea. “It will look like charity,” she said after a moment. “The sort women took and then hid when husbands came in.”

“It will be charity,” Elias said. “It will be the sort of charity you cannot be ashamed of because you can cover a jar with it.”

“And in the fibers you will,” she said, and it wasn’t a question.

“I will put nothing that will sting,” Elias said. He softened his voice as he would for a nervous dog. “Only the word that sends people back to their coats to fetch their gloves. Only the word that makes them put the kettle on before tears. Only the sound a brush makes when it finds the corner you always forget.”

Magdalene sighed. “Bring me the period,” she said. “The little dot you took as if you were stealing an egg.”

Elias did not ask her how she knew. He reached into his pocket and drew the small black speck onto his palm. It looked like nothing. It was nothing until you needed it. Magdalene did not touch it. She bent over it as if listening and the dot listened back. She nodded. “Yes,” she said. “He will hate this.” She laid a slip of transparent paper over Elias’s hand and lifted the dot’s shadow and slid that into a forme with a care like baptism. “Do not make me do this again,” she muttered, and then, because her heart had never once in its life agreed to be hardened and stay, she added, “But if you must, warn me. I will not be taken by surprise by goodness.”

They printed fifty. The paper was not fine. It was that useful brown that seems to have been born wrapped round apples. The lists came off the press with a smell like rain on a pantry. Magdalene eyed the stack as if it might run. “You will need strings,” she said. “For hanging. The backs of doors. Pegs will sulk if you leave them out.” She took a skein from a drawer and cut lengths with a knife that had been her father’s and his mother’s and—if Andover kept itself from burning down or eating its own children—would belong to a niece yet to be born. She licked her forefinger and smoothed the ends. A small gesture, a small spell. Elias loved the woman for it. He thought he had loved her already for refusing him three times and he had, but this—licked forefinger, neat ends—added itself to the tally.

On the green, where men were setting up their stalls and children were arranging coins into shapes that looked like bigger coins, Elias borrowed the town’s attention the way a bell borrows air. He stood on the flat top of the old mile stone, which had lost the number for the next place and kept the number for the one behind as if it could only bear to remember home. He did not clear his throat. He did not raise his arms. He let the sun find the list in his hand and make it glow.

“You will have pamphlets,” he said when the crowd had gathered in the way a crowd always does on a green when someone stands a little higher than the rest. “Again. Today, probably. Tomorrow certainly. He will put numbers on you. He will tell you what you are worth. He will put measurements on your children like coats. He will tell you the names of the parts of your soul and then give you the wrong definitions. He is very good at adding. He has forgotten how to count to one.”

A laugh moved through the crowd like someone trying not to cough and failing. Hester Stowe stood with both hands in her pockets and showed her teeth at the idea of anyone numbering her.

“This,” Elias said, holding up the list, “is for adding back. It is for writing what you need and what you want and what you will forgive yourself for not having when the week is out. It is for putting your name at the top of your own life. You will hang it behind the door where you keep the broom. When you think something ugly, you will write butter. When you think something mean, you will write soap. When you cannot think at all, you will draw a square where the sugar lives. If you have a neighbor who cannot read, you will go and put a square in their square. If you can read and you read the sort of word that sticks in your skin, you will come to me and I will make tea. If you have better tea than mine, I will come to you.”

Someone, and it might have been Mr. Crisp’s daughter because she had never before spent a word where a look would do and had lately begun to spend, said, low and clear, “Yes.”

Elias did not say it was magic. He did not say it was defense. He said, “Magdalene Plum has made these. You may pay her in pennies or jam. If you have neither, you may pay her in kindness and she will remember you to your credit the next time you buy thread.” Magdalene, who would not for the world be seen accepting jam as payment for paper, lifted her chin and took the first coins with a sniff that made paying in kindness feel extravagant.

Quill, bored with speeches and delighted by distribution, leaped from shoulder to shoulder with lengths of string in his mouth as if he were ribboning a maypole. He allowed three children to pet him and bit none of them. “One each,” he said sternly when Hester tried to take two. “They multiply in houses. They do not multiply in pockets.”

“They do if you tear them in half,” Hester retorted. “Two smaller lists.”

“Mathematical fraud,” Quill said. “Go stand on your brother’s foot.” She went.

The noon bells, when they came, were late. They came in a disorder like a man coming down stairs carrying too many books. Heads turned toward the tower. People whose lives ran on those twelve notes frowned. The bell rope down the church’s back corridor had a particular feel on a Saturday, rough from the week, oiled with the touch of a hundred palms. Elijah Grieves, who rang them, was a man who rarely looked up; the bell had taken its shape in him, a roundness where others were square. He came out of the side door shaking his hands as if he had dipped them in nettles.

“They were numbered,” he said, when Elias reached him on the path. “He put numbers on them. It didn’t change the sound. It did change it. I cannot say. I heard a one where there is none.” He lifted his palms. Across the pads of his fingers a row of faint gray marks had been laid like rules on paper. One, two, three, four, five. He had stopped before six.

Elias felt in his mouth the small brave word his town had been learning to say. He did not say it aloud yet. He turned Elijah’s hands and breath caught in his chest as if he had picked up something heavy wrong. The marks were not ink. They were ash. The ash had been pressed in by something that meant to teach.

“I will see the ropes,” he said. “Would you stand in the sun and forget what numbers are for a minute.”

“I do it often,” Elijah said with humility. He went to stand by the chest tomb he was not related to, and he put his face up like a man warming his bones. Elias and Quill went inside the cool blue of the church.

The great loops of rope hung like enormous, sleeping snakes. At the base of each, knots had been tied where no knots belonged: neat, tight, too small for the size of rope. Around each knot a number had been chalked on with something not chalk, something that hated skin. One. Two. Three. Elias put his palm to One. The rope resisted him. It had been taught to obey a counting that was not the bell’s own.

“You are very tidy,” he said to the nave. Dust shivered. “You are very ordered. You have the sort of order that makes girls stand up straight against walls. It is not the only sort.”

He took out one of the strings Magdalene had cut and tied it very loosely around the middle of the rope. Then he tied a second string below and a third above. He breathed out and spoke the word of setting things to rights the way a mother’s friend speaks it while she picks up the skirts of her dress and wades into the playroom. The rope shifted, thinking. The knot thought of being undone and did not yet undo. Truth did not argue. It poured tea and went on pouring when the guest sulked. Elias touched the chalk numbers with his knuckle and closed his eyes and saw the chalk before it had been chalk and the hand before it had held chalk and the boy before the hand grew big. He pressed his thumb against One and said, weary and gentle, “Enough.”

The number went out like a candle you blow and pretend someone else did. The knot unlearned itself. Two took longer. Three spat. Four came away with satisfaction; it had known it was ridiculous, stuck where it was. Five was a little blood. He wiped it on his trousers and told no one.

Outside, Elijah rolled his shoulders as if the bell had started to remember the curve of them. “Better,” he said. “He will not like that.”

“He will be late to his dinner,” Elias said. “No one likes that.” He stood on the step and looked over Andover and the way the roofs made a quilt to keep something warm underneath. He could feel another place tugging at him like a loose thread caught on a nail. North one day ago. Not north today. East. The ache had moved to under his right shoulder. “He is making lists,” he said absently. “Do not listen to them unless they say bread, salt, pickles.”

“He will put numbers on doors,” Elijah said.

“He will,” Elias agreed. “We will put flowers over them. He will say we’re foolish. We will be foolish. And we will eat.”

They were halfway down the path to the green when the first door was chalked. The child who did it was not a child; he was a man named Short John because he was long, and he held a square of gray pressed stuff and ran it across the blue of Mrs. Coppin’s door with a hunger that did not belong to his stomach. A four appeared, then a decimal, then a six. He looked at his work the way an apprentice looks at a chair he has planed smooth, and smile-pride broke over his face and then was gone as if water had thrown it out.

“John,” Elias said mildly, “you have something on your hand.”

John stared at his palm as if he had been awakened. There was no chalk there, only that not-chalk ash, settled in the whorls. He looked at the door. He looked at Elias. “I don’t,” he said, but quiet, as if the say was a question.

“You do,” Elias said. “Give it here.” He reached for John’s hand and took it as he would a rope with a house tied to the other end. “Put your other hand on your own chest,” he added, and John obeyed because people like him, who had been told to put their hands on benches and tables and planks and put them sensibly, sometimes needed directions when it came to themselves. Elias leaned forward and blew, once, on the palm. The ash scattered as if surprised to discover it had no roots. “There,” Elias said. He stepped past John and wrote over the number with the heel of his own hand, not words. He rubbed until the blue came back. He patted the wood because the wood had felt it. “Hester,” he called, without looking, “bring me a flower with a head not bigger than your nose.”

Hester came at once, as if she had been waiting behind him all his life. She had a nasturtium, violent and impossible. Elias took it and tucked it into the splinter beside the latch. “Now,” he said to the door, to Mrs. Coppin’s kitchen, to the corner where she kept the sugar, “you may look silly all afternoon. It will help.”

Mrs. Coppin, who had never been silly in any public way, laughed from inside, unoffended, and the small devil in the chalk lifted its head and lost interest. John wiped his palm on his waistcoat as if that would undo something else. “I thought I was helping,” he said, bewildered.

“You were,” Elias said. He meant it. “You were helping prove that chalk does not say God.” He felt the ache under his shoulder move and he put two fingers there and pressed. “If you feel like writing numbers,” he added to John, “write the number of your own door. It will bring you home.”

By afternoon, Andover wore flowers like a girl who had run out of ears to stick them behind. Numbers appeared and were rubbed away and were covered with leaves of ivy and the paper labels of tins of syrup. Magdalene’s lists had been hung beside brooms; the lines began to fill with butter and soap and thread and patience and more patience and forgive myself for thinking the wrong thought and a drawing of a cat with a hat on that could only have been Hester’s. Quill napped with his head inside a bowl because that way no one would put words in it. Three times the black birds that were not birds tried to batter themselves to bits on the panes of the post office.
