Three times Mr. Bobbin, who had once played the fiddle badly in a pub and wished sometimes he still did, waltzed them away with a fly whisk and the obstinate grace of a man in his shirtsleeves dancing alone.

In the midst of this, when the day might have been called a success by someone who counted wins by notches cut in door frames, Vellum Crowe sent a thing so quiet that if Hester had not been looking at Elias since morning as if she could protect him with a stare, no one would have noticed it.

It came as a boy with a tray of buttons.

He had been a boy for years and would be one for some years yet; he had the knees and the scuffed shoes and the opinion of bread that boys have. He had a tray hung from his neck with a strap and on the tray were buttons, bone and wooden and glass, buttons that had belonged to miens of coats and dresses that had been out of fashion when the King was a different man. The buttons were threaded through card and each card had two words inked at the top. Brave Girl. Honest Wife. Good Man. Faithful Son. The boy’s face was blank and not unhappy, the way faces are in the moment after someone says the first sentence in a story you have heard before. He went person to person and lifted the tray as if he were in church and the tray held wine and you had already drunk and must not take more. People took, because buttons are useful and names are a hunger.

Hester reached him before Elias did. She stood with her fists on her hips and tilted her chin until her hair touched her spine and refused Good Girl and said, “Do you have Stupid Brother.”

The boy raised his eyes and had to be a boy for three heartbeats longer than was polite. “No,” he said, through the voice of someone who wished he could peach and could not. “Only these.”

“What if I am not good and not a girl,” Hester said, tempted by fairies and devils both, “but something else.”

The boy hesitated. He looked down at his tray and reached for a card and stopped and reached for another. His fingers hovered above Truth Teller. He lifted it as if it were heftless and heavy, which it was, and he would have pinned it on her chest if Elias had not touched his wrist. The boy startled and came back into himself like a man into a cold room. His eyes filled with tears because his eyes had been about to be taken from him. He put the card back. “I’m sorry,” he said, to Hester, to Elias, to the buttons.

“It’s not you,” Elias said, to the boy and to the town and to himself. “Go home. Give those to Magdalene. She will string them on the right names.” He lifted the tray off the boy’s neck and the boy sagged with relief and ran. The buttons made a small rain on the green when the tray tilted. Elias crouched and picked up Truth Teller. The card tried to stick to his finger and he gave it one firm look and it changed its mind. He slid the card into his pocket behind the dot and felt the two sit there together like knowledge and action.

“Will you give it to me,” Hester demanded, because she had heard the words and claimed them with the instantaneous greed of a thief with a code. “Will you pin it on. If you do, it will stick.” She sounded as if she wanted a brand. Quill made a sound not unlike the light failing in a lamp. He came and stood between Hester and the card with such careful rudeness that Hester had to look him in the face. He had cat angles. He had cat eyes. They were currently two very small moons.

“You will not wear any word today,” Quill said. He did not hiss. He did not purr. He pronounced. “You will eat. You will run. You will say three times my name is Hester Stowe and the only thing true in that sentence is that I am not a stove. You will laugh at yourself because you are very funny. You will not hold out your chest for anyone’s pin.” He flicked her jumper with a paw, less than the tap you might give a child’s shoulder with your knuckle when she is dreaming. Hester’s chin came down. She did as she was told. She looked smaller. She went away to be large somewhere else.

“Buttons,” Elias muttered, when she had gone. “He will send mirrors next. He will call himself a philanthropist.”

“He will send knives measured in kindnesses,” Quill said, disgusted. “All dull. All sharp.”

They walked the green until shadows began to think seriously about work. They rubbed away numbers. They hung lists. They put flowers in places that were very stern about flowers. Elias took three complaints and swallowed them without chewing because he did not have time to argue with Mrs. Hardesty about whether her sausages had suffered; they had not. He drank tea offered and tea taken and a tea that was not tea at all but barley boiled with a bay leaf because someone’s grandmother had done it that way and no one had stopped her. He made a small boy swallow a lie he had just heard and then take a sip of water because swallowing things dry is foolish. He stood under a tree and looked north and east and west in turn and felt each direction press against him like a dog leaning its weight. He had said he would go where Vellum wanted him not to go and Vellum wanted him not to stay. So he stayed. No heroism. Only a man in a town where he lived.

Night now had a shadow on it that it had not had before. People went home not briskly, not slow. They went home as if something were following and something else were leading and they were trying to arrange themselves between. Elias went indoors and lit his small lamp because he preferred oil to gas when he was going to do something that ought to have the right sort of flame. He set the biscuit tin on the table and took the pamphlets out and considered them the way a farmer might consider a dead fox: not with sentiment, not without a spasm of something like anger. He lifted the lid of the bottom of his teapot and took out what he had hidden there a year ago because he did not know why he had hidden it and it felt important. A thin strip of ribbon. It was the ribbon his mother had tied round her hair when she wanted it out of her eyes to scrub. It had a song in it. It had water. It had the smell of soap made from fat that had been saved and saved and finally used. He laid the ribbon across the pamphlets and said the name he never said, the one under his own. “All right,” he said, to the paper, to the ribbon, to the piece of his life that had found him at his table. “We will be with each other now.”

Quill came very slowly and put his paw on Elias’s wrist with the delicacy of a prince who knows the weight of a crown and refuses it. Elias did not begin to cry and he did not begin to look heroic. He breathed. The ribbon lay and lay and did what ribbons do when they have been taught all their lives to hold. The papers seemed to find themselves less interesting and more tiresome. The nasty burr in the second one shifted as if it had been dislodged by a careless elbow and fell apart. The first one thought of its title and then of its margin and then of the weed in the margin and then of the root of the weed and went home. Elias took them up and put them back in the tin and set the book and the stone and his hand on top in turn and did not worry if there was a formula in the order. There was and there wasn’t; that was life.

“You will go tomorrow,” Quill said eventually into the quiet that had deepened like the color of water at dusk.

“I will go in the morning,” Elias said. “Before the day puts its boots on. He took his dinner late; he will sleep late. He will think I have forgotten where the door to the lower rooms is. He will think I have decided to be a broom forever and never a brush.”

“You are not a brush,” Quill said. “A brush is for paint. You are for corners.”

“Different sorts,” Elias said. He stretched his fingers and looked at their tips as if there might be a reckoning under the nails. Five little numbers there. No ash. “He will ask me to be numbered,” he added. “He will ask me to tell him what I am in his words. He will say I am a sad son and I will flinch because it is true and not his. He will say I am a man who tidies in order not to grieve. I will say that grief leaves crumbs and someone must sweep.”

“You will say it,” Quill said, satisfied. “Say the thing he cannot say without eating a part of himself that he wants to keep.”

The dawn came with a taste of tin. The sky had beaten itself flat to lay better over Andover; something to do with pressure and weather and the way fields lie in late autumn. Elias put his hands on the table palms down and pressed, as if he could fasten himself to the world so that if a wind came and played tricks he would not be the leaf in it. He put the dot in his pocket and the Truth Teller card next to it and the ribbon round the pamphlets and the soldier in his breast, foolishly, because he had liked its weight on the press and thought the press might have liked its weight back. He did not tell Quill to stay. Quill did not ask to go. They went.

The school was less sentient in the morning. It had not yet remembered its damp. The steps were slick but not malicious. Elias left his hand on the wall as he went down and told it an unimportant thing as if to keep it in conversation: the way Mrs. Coppin put her spoon on a plate and not on the stove back and how he had learned to do the same. The wall did not reply. It listened. Sometimes that was enough.

At the door to the lower room, where ink had slept, a new sign had been hung. It had been thumbtacked—no spell—just hit and held. It said, in precise hand-done capitals, PRIVATE INSTRUCTION. There was a line drawn under it so straight that it had to be wrong. Elias wanted to pull the sign down and write underneath it, NO CHILDREN, but he did not. He opened the door.

Vellum Crowe was awake. He had not slept. He had been awake, learning. He had a cup on the table and something that might have been soup in it and he had not eaten. He had his sleeves rolled up and his thin forearms were scribbled with ink formulas because he was the sort of man who remembers better when his own skin agrees to be paper. He looked at Elias and in the single breath they took together, something like relief crossed his face. It was a man’s relief when he hears the footstep coming that will not be turned away.

“You stayed,” Vellum said. “You did not come when I told you to. You made errands. And lists. You are trite.”

“I am durable,” Elias said. “You can write me as clever or not clever as you like. I will still be here when your pen runs out.”

Vellum’s mouth did an unwise thing then; it softened. He caught it and straightened it with a touch that would have been tender if it had been on anyone’s flesh but his own. “Say what you came to say,” he commanded, and each word struck the air and pressed wrinkles into it that would not smooth easily. “Say it. We will name. We will put the correct nouns with the correct verbs. You are a broom.”

“I am a man,” Elias said. He took the dot from his pocket and did not show it. He put his hand, that hand that had been taught by a woman who sang, on the end of the press as if to introduce two old creatures. “You are a boy who forgot what his mother called him,” he added, not cruel, not kind. He added, after a small time in which Vellum remembered to blink, “I brought you a soldier.”

The look Vellum gave the painted thing on the table was so quick you might have missed it if you were the sort to miss things on purpose. Elias was not. Vellum’s throat worked. “I do not play,” he said.

“You do not stop,” Elias said. “Which is not the same.” He took the truth card from his pocket and the dot with it and set them together on the press. “You sent buttons. You sent words to wear. You sent numbers. You sent whispers that teach women to lay children down and call it safety. You know how to thread malice. I know how to unthread it. If I die of it one day, at least the last thing I will have eaten will not be a lie.”

Vellum’s eyes flicked to the door and back. He was checking the room to be certain it stayed his. “You would die as easily as a word,” he said. It was intended to be threat. It sounded like the thing men say when they love a sentence on a page and cannot get it out in any human way.

“Then put me down with the good ones,” Elias said. He looked Vellum in the eyes because men had already been told not to and because Hester had done it for him when she laughed and said she was not a stove. “You will put my mother in your next pamphlet. You have already written a paragraph about her in your head. You have written a sentence in which she did not come home for two days and a second in which she did and a third in which there was someone with her and a fourth in which there was no one and the fourth is the worst of them because it has nothing pointed to it except absence and you will let people fill it with whatever dirt they have near to hand. If you write it, I will find you and I will take your name and sew it into my pocket and you will have to come to me to ask for it back.”

Vellum’s hands, which had been practicing composure for fifty mornings, curled in on themselves as if they might learn to be fists. “You think you are a hero,” he said. Not a sneer. A boy trying on a tone and finding it too big.

“I think I am necessary,” Elias said. “I am not alone. My town knows where its tea is. The truth does not have to be shouted down the street. It will be put on the back of a door and looked at before someone leaves for the market.” He laid the truth card with its neat little letters face down. He held the dot on the center of it with his thumb. “We are going to set something down,” he said, and the press creaked as if clearing its own throat. “And we are going to leave it there.”

Vellum moved faster than Quill liked. He picked up a handful of letters and he threw them, and each was meant to be a nail. Quill did a thing he despised, which was to look like a fool for usefulness’s sake: he thrust himself between the letters and Elias and let them tangle in his fur because his fur was the sort of thing malicious words slide off when they have not planned for whiskers. He spat, ugly. He sank his teeth in liar and it tasted of bitter almonds and the moment when a sweet goes bad on your tongue. He swallowed anyway. He felt it crawl and then he was Quill hard, that line of cat that goes from nose to tail like a string plucked. He hissed and disliked himself for hissing and did it again.

“I know your name,” Elias said, to Vellum, with the dot under his thumb and the card under the dot and the ribbon in his pocket and the soldier waiting with his badly painted nose. “Not the one you chose. The one someone else said to you without clothes on it. I do not need to say it. It is a small name. It is the name of a boy in a room being told not to point. You will not like me for this. You will not be able to make a pamphlet that does not smell of mildew if you write me into it.” He lifted his thumb. He did not speak a spell. He said the word that lives in every house and men forget where it lives because they walk past it to get to the door. “Full stop,” he said. “There.”

It was not light. It was not noise. It was the end of a sentence that had been running through the town for two days. It found the place in Mrs. Hardesty’s kitchen where she kept the jar for flour and it sat in the bottom of it and waited to be scooped. It found the bell the boys rang with their fists when Elijah was not looking and it put a little period on the sound so that it could not run on into Ugly Theories About The Vicar’s Sister. It found the place on Hester’s mouth where a laugh had worn the skin thin and it settled there and made a small punctuation that felt like a healed scab. It found the pamphlets in the tin on Elias’s table and laid a dot on the dot and said, without voice or bravado, enough.

Vellum Crowe swayed. He had been standing on the run-on. He had been breathing the breath people breathe when they are waiting for the next clause to give them their excuse. He put his hand out as if there were a chair and there was none—he had turned them into splinters because he was a fool—and he did not fall because falling would have been a drama and he was not written for drama, only for the nibbling bitterness of men in rooms. He said, very quietly, “You cannot print this.”

“No,” Elias agreed. “It doesn’t read. It sits.” He touched the press, which had begun to look thoughtful, as presses do when you tell them you will not be using them for their ordinary wickedness and they are not sure they like virtue. “You could set it,” he said to the iron. “You could do it by hand in churches and rooms where fights start and walk away once it takes.” He lifted his hand and looked at Vellum and saw suddenly how thin the man had been made by his own wanting. The pity that came into him then had four legs and a tail. It was a cat. He did not show it. He said instead, “Would you like soup.”

Vellum looked at him as if he had said Would you like death. He made a face that was supposed to be disdain and could not be because he had turned his disdain into a pet and it had run away. “You will not make me into a story where we sit and share food and I learn to call you by your Christian name,” he said. “You will not feed me.”

“You are already in my story,” Elias said. “And you are very hungry.” He took a step back, because pity was dangerous in the presence of a man who sharpened it for sport. “I am going home,” he said, because truth sometimes has doors in it and you must go through. “If you come up into the air I will speak to you. If you send paper to children I will stand in your doorway every morning until you stop and my town will bring me bread on days I am tired.”

Vellum did not answer. His mouth had forgotten the trick. He looked at the soldier and turned away as if embarrassed by his own embarrassment. He lifted the cup that might have had soup in it and drank and choked because you cannot drink numbers and be satisfied.

On the steps, Elias let himself sit down for a long breath and then another. Quill arranged his whiskers with the lethal delicacy of a swordsman cleaning his blade. “If you ever,” he said to Elias without heat, “ask me to swallow liar again, I will sleep in the drawer with the spoons and I will let them all have my fur forever.”

“You’d be handsome in spoons,” Elias said. “Think of the reflection.” He leaned the back of his head against the stone and watched a spider do mathematics without numbers in the corner, putting leg to leg to silk to wall with neither chalk nor ash nor any man’s pin. He looked at the morning, which was not much older than it had been when he’d left the house, and thought how lengthened it felt already, like a day at the sea. “We are not done,” he said.

“No,” Quill said. “But you put a dot in the right place.” He looked at Elias, and there was a thought in his yellow eyes that was not cat and not human and not town either. “He is one of those who has forgotten to want anything that doesn’t have a label.”

“He wanted that soldier,” Elias said. “He was six for a moment. People will tell you six is harmless. It is not. Six is violent. Six will learn a word and say it until it cuts and then cry because it cut and say it again for the shape of it. I will remember he wanted a toy. It will matter.”

They walked home through a town that was discovering in a small way what it was to end a sentence. People spoke to each other and then stopped and smiled and did not say the extra nasty thought that had been waiting to come out like a rash. Mrs. Hardesty hung a list and put on it apples, lard, don’t listen, more apples. Mr. Bobbin tuned his fiddle and decided not to play. Elijah Grieves rang the bells at the right hour and mistook a tone for another and did not mind, which was a revolution in a church taller than its own thought.

On Elias’s table, under the stone and the book and his hand, two pieces of wicked paper behaved themselves with a sulk that would not last. He removed his hand. The book could sit alone. He thought of writing a notice and pinning it to his own door with a thumbtack that smelled of tin. PRIVATE INSTRUCTION, it would say, and underneath, in smaller letters, TEA.

He did not do it. He put the kettle on. He sat on his step. He looked at the street. Hester came and sat beside him without asking because only a very few people in a man’s life get to do that, and she had given him a frog and two coins and nearly her trust and then her laugh, so she was in. They looked at the town together, and then at nothing, and that was fine.

“I stole something from the buttons,” Hester said eventually, as if confessing and bragging were the same thing. “The one that said honest wife. I gave it to Mrs. Troon. She laughed and put it in her pocket.”

“Good,” Elias said. “Put things in your pockets. Then when a wind comes there will be weight there and you will not be turned inside out.”

“My brother said you only win because you talk like stories do and talking isn’t anything,” Hester said. “I said he only loses because he listens like a donkey.” She leaned against him, not much, a little weight. “Is it winning,” she asked, because there was nothing child in the question and everything child in the asking.

“It is ending a sentence,” Elias said. “It is putting a pot on the table and saying This is your spoon, this is mine. It is making lists and rubbing chalk. It isn’t much. It is more than nothing.” He thought of Vellum in his room smelling of ash and difficult childhood and soup he wouldn’t eat. “It is not winning,” he said, and Hester heard the word not because she wore a Truth invisible and that made words closer to her skin. “It is refusing to lose in the way that would please him.”

Quill made a sound like bridal lace. He had caught the fly with the inadequate imagination somewhere between Magdalene’s and the green and was groomingly satisfied with himself. “He will send something clever,” he said, licking a paw and dragging it over an ear as if the job were finishing touches. “He is clever. It’s the thing he knows about himself.”

“I know,” Elias said. He looked at the afternoon. It did not look back in any meaningful way. He thought of the dot, of the card, of the ribbon. He thought of his mother’s song. He put his hands on his knees and was not idle. He was waiting the way bakers wait: by doing something with flour.

Vellum, in the room below the school where the maps had learned to be not countries, took up a fresh sheet and made it into a shape like a boat because he had forgotten to do that for thirty years and sometimes forgetting and remembering are different sorts of spells. He pushed the paper boat across the surface of his soup and thought of a river that would have been a friend if he had not told it he was smarter than it. He pushed the boat under. He watched it sink. He smiled a very small smile that had no malice in it and so died as it left his mouth.

Andover breathed in and out and gathered its own smell round itself like a shawl. Someone somewhere called a cat in and the cat came and then went back out because that is what cats do when called. The water meadows were a breath away from letting mist stand up and show its bones. The green went dull and then lit again with a boy’s torch that should not have been out and was. Elias took up his broom because some spells you have to make again and again or the world forgets and then where are you. He swept his step because it was his step. He did not put numbers on the broom. He did not let anyone else. He thought, without argument, that there would be a morning when he would, for a little, not be able to end any sentence, but he was not going to give that morning this day’s light. He went inside when the dark said so in a voice that was not a pamphlet. He shut the door because he had a door. He put the kettle on again because kettles are how you mark distance between the worst of a man’s words and the best of what you can do about them. He sat. He stood. He kept both hands. He did not glow. He prepared.

Saturday’s second breath brought things in their Sunday clothes, which was to say they concealed themselves as virtue. The first boy came up the lane with his cap at an angle that made old women say things about the cut of his mother’s tongue, and he had a sheaf of small papers tied neat with twine. There was nothing written on them. They carried a smell like boiled milk left to catch a skin. He put them into people’s hands with his head respectfully bent as if he were doffing it without the bother, and each paper had a pin like a thorn stuck through one corner so that you could put it on a sleeve. The title, if you held it to the light and let your eyes go strange, was Apology. Under it, there were no words at all.

They worked like sacks. Mrs. Hardesty took one and a small hollowness came loose in her mouth so that when the girl who swept her step every Thursday came late and knocked a tray of feet-first rabbits with her elbow and made a mess of sawdust and ears, Mrs. Hardesty went to say the word she had always used as a hinge—sorry—and found that the hinge had been prised up and hidden under the floorboard. She stood with her hands on her hips and said, hearing herself as if someone else had set her to it, I suppose. She disliked the sound so much she nearly paid the girl double to wash it out. The girl, who had her own blank pinned to her jumper, stared at Mrs. Hardesty as if a sovereign had rolled under the counter and no one had it in them to kneel.

Magdalene Plum took one from the boy because she never refused to take what arrived in her hand; she liked to look at wickedness where it could see her looking. She pricked her finger on the pin and refused to be taught by that either. She turned the paper. She held it to the window. She laid it on her press as a dare and the press—in whose metal had been hammered a dozen sermons by men whose daughters had grown up and grown old within the smell of it—refused to act as midwife. “Hmph,” Magdalene said. She wrapped the blank like bread in an old page of the Hampshire Chronicle that had reported nothing bloodier than a harvest and sent it with a boy to Elias.

He was on his knees under Mrs. Troon’s table at the time, extracting a splinter that had been working up through the wood toward the soft underside of the baby. He extricated things with his voice when he could, but splinters liked a knife if you respected the fiber and the grain. He came out dusty and pleased with the chair leg, and took the package without ceremony, and the blank slid out and made the smallest noise like a little breath of contentment, as if at last it had found someone who would be a good host.

“Don’t pin it,” Quill said immediately, all hackles in his voice if not his fur. “Don’t put it anywhere it can learn the shape of your arm.”

“I won’t,” Elias murmured. He touched the corner of the page with one knuckle. The nothing in it tried to come up his hand and grease his palm and he said, very quietly, as you would to an overeager dog: “No.” He smelled the trick of it: the way it would sit on a sleeve all morning and then, when a man dropped an egg in the yard and a neighbor said, ah, and not unkindly, it would suck the apology out of his mouth and replace it with a bit of furniture dressed as a sentence. An apology was a use. This was an ornament, the sort a rich woman wears to church and takes off before the potatoes are peeled. “Clever,” he said, because it was; Vellum had found the place where the town gave itself back to itself most easily and set a hand on it.

By midmorning there were two more contrivances. A man with a face like a knitting mistake brought round little mirrors with rough tin edging and a slip of paper in each that read with printed courtesy For Your Self-Reflection from A Friend. If you held a mirror up you could not see your nose straight for the words they had pressed behind the silver, and if you looked long enough the edge of your mouth took on the shape of the word that lay closest, which made men look cruel when they were tired and women look tired when they were trying to be cruel. Children took them by the dozen because children take shining things; Hester took one and put it in her pocket and later hung it facing the wall with a sock over it and told it, “Not until you behave.”

And a woman I will not name because she had once refused a half-penny from a boy who had tried to pay for his mother’s button with it came up the High Street ringing a small clean handbell and selling cards with lines on them and one word in tidy copperplate at the top: Regret. “You fill in your own,” she told Magdalene, who frowned as if the word regret should not have let itself be put on a string and dragged about. “Then it’s real. Then everyone sees and knows you have been honest enough to be wrong.” Nothing in her voice suggested she had thought any of this by herself. She had a look to her as though Vellum had pressed her flat and written on her and when he lifted his hand she had sprung back up with his letters ghosting under her skin.

Elias took the mirror, and the blank, and the regret, and laid them in a row on his table with the ribbon beyond them like a line he did not mean them to cross. He said nothing to them because there is a kind of rudeness that encourages the worst sort of houseguest and he had had lodgers enough in his time. He went and knocked on Magdalene’s lintel so that she would have the pleasure of frowning at him in the doorway and then telling him he knew better. “He is trying to replace breath with paper,” he told her when she had finished. “He has understood we have a word for We are sorry and we give it away to one another and it comes back and it is not the poorer for it. He has made it a thing you wear when you remember.”

“Then take their pins,” Magdalene said, savage. She cut a piece of brown wrap from the roll with a movement like a woman slicing a loaf, and printed with small brutality down the middle of it: lend, mend, carry, walk, brew, wash, spare. “You have taught them to write butter and soap. Teach them to write the doing words. Put these in their kitchens. Hang them on the line and let the verbs learn the shape of wind.” She looked at him without love and with all the respect she had. “Do not make me say please,” she added. “If this is to be the language of the day, I will not be poor in it.”

He left Magdalene’s with a stack under his arm and the press’s heat still under his palms. On the green, he gave the verbs away as if he were tossing seed into a fallow field and seeing already the rough hair of shoots coming up. Women took them and smiled with their mouths, which said everything about what men had been doing to their mouths all morning. Men took them and tucked them into hats because hats remember things that heads forget. Children ran with them held high and the words flapped and learned to fly and were not upset when they fell; verbs are not like that.

Quill carried string again in his teeth and looked as if the task were beneath him and entirely pleasing at once. “He will hate this,” the cat said around the knot, mouth full of a helpfulness he could not forbear. “Not because it is clever. Because it is plain. He can’t climb plain.”

“I should like a sentence he cannot climb,” Elias said. He raised his voice exactly as much as he needed to be heard by those near enough to want to hear and not a breath more. “Hang them over where water runs,” he called. “Sinks that don’t keep their tempers. Pumps. By the well. And say the words when you use them. Not to make a spell. To listen to whether they have changed shape in your mouth.”

The hush came at two o’clock. It came like snow in a dream: suddenly, totally, and with a ridiculous gentleness that made you forget it had weight. Elias was leaning on the pump handle on the green, showing a boy where it stuck in the downstroke, when the silence dropped and muffled them and left their breath singing under their skin like kettles on an invisible hob. The boy’s mouth opened for a word he always said when he wanted the handle pulled harder and all that came out was a bit of air shaped like a letter with nothing after it. Elias felt his own tongue slip back from certain syllables as if they had become hot and his mouth did not care to be burned. He tried the old household words—yes, no, please, thank you—and found he had them, poor but his. Sorry, though, would not be caught; it scooted to the back of his throat like a mouse who had been a mouse a while and meant to go on.

People stood where they were and went still, not with the stillness of prayer but with the stillness of a man who suddenly cannot call his child. Hester did not notice. Hester set her jaw against a thing and it always gave. She laughed at the hush because it had forgotten to take laughter too, and then stopped because Mrs. Hardesty had put both hands to her cheeks and had turned the kind of color that makes a person one sort of liar or another. The mirror-seller turned his mirrors over and over as if they might give him back a sound if he shook them. The apology sheets quivered like a flock catching a draft and then lay flat, very pleased with themselves in a way that made Quill want, for the first time in his elegant life, to shred something without leaving it neat in the end.

Elias did the one thing he was always certain of in a minute when he had nothing else to be certain of. He pumped. The pump was an old one and grudged the first pull in any weather and sulked if the weather had changed without telling it. He put his back under the work. He used not strength but steadiness. Water came up like a thing remembering itself; it shouldered into the spout with a growl like a wakeful stomach and fell. He had hung one of Magdalene’s lists of verbs under the bracket just an hour before and now the water ran a finger along the word brew and made it shine, and along the word wash and set a wet edge on it, and along spare and made it look foolish for a second and then grand. He set the cup under, the communal one that tasted faintly of iron and of every mouth that had found itself at the green with its own cup left in the sink, and he drank. He swallowed with deliberation as if the water might be something else if not supervised. He put the cup in Hester’s hands and made the same face at her he would make over any child dawdling with cold porridge.

She drank. She dabbed at her lip with her knuckle. She said the word impossible for a girl of nine that lives in the hands and then blushed because it came out with a roundness that made an impossible thing soft. “Say please,” Elias told the boy who had wanted the handle pulled, and the boy thought for one courageous second the pumpman had gone mad and then he said it, with a wobble, and his mouth cried out in relief to discover he still had that door. The sorry would come back later; it was not the sort to be fetched with a bucket.

Around them the hush pushed and pressed and found stubbornness in places where it expected compliance. At Magdalene’s, the press went on making the small soft sound it makes when a woman is doing work no one knows about, and the hush could not find a way to get into the oil of that. In the church, Elijah Grieves set his hands on the rope and spoke into his fists the names of his sons and the bell heard and answered and the names did not stick to the clapper but went up and were set to ring and came down again and became bread in Elijah’s mouth when he had been skipping lunches to finish a coffin in time. In Mrs. Troon’s kitchen, where the apology sheet had been pinned above the baby’s cot with too much pride, the baby took his own hand, the left one, and put the knuckles into his mouth and chewed on his fingers and made the sound babies make before they learn any words and it was such a sound that the hush, which had no idea what to do with the untidy, took another step back.

It would have held, might have held, if Vellum had been content with a single cleverness. He had sent the hush and thought to watch the town press its face to it and leave a shape there and had gone away to map the next cruelty in thin blue pencil and wonder whether there was an economy in saving certain vowels for a storm. But he was not that sort. He could not resist improving a plan. He sent footnotes.

They fell like moths. They were small slips with glue on the back so old-fashioned women smiled and thought of ration books, and they landed on people’s sleeves and hats and cheeks and carried a word in tiny, neat type: Actually. You could not see it without making yourself into a person who peers. But peering is a habit in towns and so the footnotes stuck and when a woman began to speak about the price of sugar she heard in the back of her head a small voice she would have cached as merely mean, and it said actually and then told her she had not got it quite right, and she paused, and in that pause there is where you can pour poison or tea depending on what country you live in.

Elias felt one land on his neck like a fly that had put on its Sunday suit. He slapped it as he had not slapped a thing since he was twelve. It stuck to his palm, and he held it out to Quill, and the cat read it with a narrowed eye. “This,” the cat said, “is an insect with footnotes attached.”

“If I peel it off in the wrong direction it will tell my skin I have misremembered my own name,” Elias said. He took the edge with two fingernails and lifted. It clung. He lifted more. It did what insinuations do when forced into daylight; it became ridiculous. He held the actually up by its tiny corner and it swayed in an unseen breeze like laundry that has no right to be pretty and yet is. He stuck it to the pump handle. “Not today,” he told it, and meant the habit and the whole damp country the habit lives in.

The boy with the apology takes—the same boy, you could see him under the shape this job had pressed him to wear—stood with his cap in his hands and tears climbing his throat. “He said I’d be paid if I didn’t talk,” he muttered, because there are men who put silence on boys like a coat and then wonder why they grow with their arms held oddly. “He said to pin them as high as I could reach. That makes it work better.”

Elias reached out and took his cap and put it back on his head with the care you’d use to position a starling. “Thank you for telling me,” he said, and it came out raw because the hush had tried to take thank you and not quite succeeded. “Take off the pins you can reach. He will not end you for it. If he tries, tell him we don’t allow endings on a Saturday.” He gave the boy a list with brew on it and a string. He gave him the cup. He did not give him a word to wear. The boy took the string and it steadied him as if he had been given a pole for a river crossing.

By evening, the clevernesses had soured in Vellum’s mouth. The hush had settled where hushed people live—under the backs of throats and behind doors men close when a song starts that was not theirs—and the footnotes had stuck to church pews and the underside of crockery and learned nothing. People put flowers over numbers and found they had invented a holiday without meaning to. The mirrors had begun to collect a slick of breath which is the most democratic medium in which to write. With a rag that never got quite clean, Mrs. Coppin wiped I am very tired of this off a glass and felt better in her elbows because the truth had somewhere to be that did not bump her in the night.

Quill slept badly when he slept at all. The liar he had swallowed the day before turned in him as if letters had bones. He lay very still and then shook as if he were dreaming water at the roots of his fur. Elias sat beside him and hated him fiercely for being vulnerable and loved him with a patience he did not give to himself. He dripped chamomile on his tongue and the cat licked as if he had been robbed of the right to be dignified and would reclaim it later with interest. At one point, near dawn, Quill woke enough to say, voice not his and entirely his, “You must stop him sending the kind that make people polite. The cruel kind a person will argue with. The polite kind builds rooms in them.”

“I know,” Elias said. He did know. It had been in the little black mouth of the period when he had put it in his pocket, the old instruction of the old law: beware the kindness that reads as charity and tastes of rank. He listened to the town breathing. It was falling into the habit of keeping its own noise, the good noise of spoons, pipe smoke, the bang of a cupboard that somebody in a hurry promised not to do again and would do again and be forgiven because a house without a bang is dead. He took the mirror from the shelf and turned it face down, not because it had done anything that day but because it had looked like it might. He looked at the ribbon on the tin and the soldier on the shelf and touched both without thinking which one first and then noticed, with a dark sort of humor, that it mattered to him and to nobody else.

At midmorning a thin letter pushed itself under his door like a rat ashamed to be seen but too hungry not to beg. It smelled of paste and the particular grief of rooms with coal without fire. Elias opened it with his thumbnail because knives have their dignity and he would not use one on an envelope that did not deserve it. The handwriting was unexpectedly cramped. Vellum had not learned to look like he had been to school. The letter said three things before it ran aground. It said: I retract. It said: The child by the river would have gone in if I had not. It said: You think because you make your town into a bowl you will keep soup from the floor, but I know the weakness of bowls.

Elias folded it. He put it on the table. He did not show it to Quill because the cat had hate for only certain sorts of paper and he did not mean to season the others. He took up Magdalene’s verbs. He thought about bowls. He thought about the way bowls break and are mended with a line of tin so fine the eye likes the scar. He thought about his mother’s ribbon and the way she had tied one end off round a leg and made a cradle of tight cloth for for drying wet boots so they did not warp. He went to the pump.

At the pump he met not the town but time. Elijah was there, his hair like a thatch the wind had tried to lift and failed because it had been laid with love. Mr. Crisp, who sharpened knives and opinions and sometimes did both too finely. Mrs. Hardesty with both hands scrubbed clean because she was afraid of what her hands might otherwise write. Hester with her pocket weighed down by a mirror and a frog memory and a stolen honesty. And Magdalene with ink on her knuckles as if she had been wagering with a raven and meant to win without letting it have the satisfaction of taking her bright things.

“We will sing,” Elias said.

Hester groaned in anticipation and delight because she saw herself on the point of making a racket with permission. Mr. Crisp began to disapprove by habit. Magdalene looked him in the eye and the disapproval turned into a convenient cough. Elijah set his feet apart like a man making space in himself for a second gear. Mrs. Hardesty had that look people get when they don’t have it in them and are going to anyway.

“Not hymns,” Elias said, because he knew his town. “We will do the one my mother sang when the wash water goes soapy. We will do the one the men learned when the mill broke and they had to carry their own jaws. We will do the one you only sing when there is something on the floor you can’t look at and you will look at it later but first you must not fall.” He spoke the words forward, not up, and they landed as if the green had put out its palm. “You know them,” he said. “Every house knows them.”

They began badly, which is always a mercy. Hester came in with too much light. Elijah’s low note had a wobble that sounded like a bell getting its legs. Mrs. Hardesty doled out the beat as if it were a ration. Magdalene’s voice was exactly true and too grieved to be beautiful, which made it something else entirely. Quill, who could sing when he wished to, lay with one paw over his nose and hummed in a dignified way because he despised singing that did not yet know what it was about. The pump took the measure and sang about iron. The list of verbs, wet now and gone wavy like hair, spoke its little lines into the falls. The hush came forward to listen. It tried to sit in the laps of the people on the green. It tried to spread itself under them like a blanket and make them mistake that weight for safety. But singing is what breath does when it refuses to be contained, and the hush, which is a liar in a lace cap, hates nothing so much as breath that will go on making itself heard even in a room with the curtains drawn.

They sang Noon Pot on, and Pick Up, and Put Down, and Sparrows Are Free to Come In and Out, which last is exactly what it sounds like and not a metaphor at all; a ritual for opening the kitchen window when a thing with wings is in the room and the adrenaline makes you stupid. They sang the silly one about the eel in the jar you can’t get back out without breaking the jar and how sometimes the right thing is to break the jar. They sang and the apologies peeled themselves off sleeves as if they worried they would spoil their finery where there was sweat. They sang and the blossoms of footnotes curled at the edges where tea steam got at them and the glue failed and fell in little guilty flakes. They sang and they found sorry again, not because you can sing it back like a name but because the muscle knew the shape of the word when it was used properly and allowed it. People said it and it was ugly and useful and made space where shame had been pretending to be furniture.

Vellum heard them, you may be sure. The school’s lower room snarled its damp and still could not muffle the sound of breath being used for something besides apology. He stood with his hands on the press and his cheekbones sharp because he did not eat when he was working and he was always working, and he smiled a schoolmaster’s smile without boys. “You think this makes you a village,” he said aloud to the iron, because he liked to win his arguments in a room where no one would say he was wrong. “You think this makes you small enough to avoid the larger ideas.” He ran his thumb over a block that had said faithfully for fifty years at the bottom of invoices and came away with a black mark he would not notice until it had dried and become a bruise people would take for a wound and would not be wrong. “Very well,” he said, to the press, to the part of himself that had never been taught to sing. “Let us see if they fancy a map.”

Quill slept by inches and woke by inches and in the waking had no patience for poetry. “He will take the names off the fields,” he said, the same way you would say a thing about weather when your bones tell you about it before the sky. “If the fields don’t have names they go shabby and let anyone in. He will make One, Two, Three, and nobody will know where Daniel’s Oat and Margaret’s Drop and The Square With The Hole In It are. People will say turn left at One and never get home.”

Elias put the cup into the cat’s offended mouth. “Drink,” he said. He turned over the bone disk that hung on the wall by the peg—a thing that had been a button and become a token and was now, in its quieter life, both—and read the names he had scratched there in a boy’s hand with a nail the day he had first been given tea at Magdalene’s: Daniel’s Oat. Margaret’s Drop. The Square With The Hole In It. The Cop, which everyone called that and no one knew why. He felt his name for them press back as if a child had put his palm against his in a game. He thought about the ache under his shoulder, which had moved again, west this time, into the part of him that always insisted he could carry more than he ought. He thought about a man downstairs in a school who believed in lines and thought they should be straight. He tied his scarf and did not bother to get the ends even. “Come on,” he said to Quill, to Hester perched on the step like a bird in possession of a house, to himself. “We’re walking the fields.”

They took paths whose ownership was a quarrel in three counties and a religion in two cottages, and Elias put his hand on every stile. He listened on the top of the wooden steps for whether the field on the far side said its name back to him and when it did not he said it to the air and nailed it there without nails. In Daniel’s Oat, there was a plan under the ground like a frost pattern on glass: long lines and right angles and little squares numbered with a drafting-minded malice. He stood with his feet in the requisite furrow and told the plan it could have his boots but not the shape of the man inside them. He stamped. The pattern rattled and went you do not understand the economy of this, Elias, and he said yes, I do, it’s called smaller wages and larger secrets, and the frost crawled away to find a muddy puddle to look noble in.

They crossed into Margaret’s Drop, where the ground had a habit of pitching you slightly toward the ditch no matter how sober you were, and he said the name and felt the field find the weight of it again. Hester ran ahead and took a candy from her pocket and broke it in two and then in two again and if you worry about such things you will be pleased to know she accounted for the fractions out loud as if there were a mathematical ghost in the grass who could be soothed by sweet and sums. Quill leaped from post to post with a care for mud princely and absurd, then dropped into the ruts like a common cat and came out with one paw black and his dignity badly dinged and licked it until the field, which had been considering giving up and becoming a lawn, remembered that it liked beasts.

By the time the light was gold and unambitious, they had walked the Square With The Hole In It and the Cop and two whose names Elias had not scratched on his button but could find with his soles: One With Three Stone Teeth, and The Afterthought. In three of them were staked small neat signs with numbers: Field 4. Lot 2. Parcel 7. This was the cleverness: the numbers had been pressed in with a traveling stamp until the post itself had learned them, an ache in the grain. Elias took off his scarf and wrapped it round the first post and leaned a moment until he felt the number give a little, like a stiff knee when you put your hand under the back of it and say, come on then, bend. He took the second post in his arms and felt ridiculous and refused to mind. He put his forehead to the third and told it a joke about a plough and a priest and the field did not laugh but the post eased and that was enough.

On their way home, with the sky taking its coins back and the hedges pretending they had never had faces, they passed under the school’s windows. In one of them, just visible if you were the sort who looked, a paper hung with a drawing on it so elegant in its cruelty it made Magdalene catch her breath in her kitchen and drop a spoon she would not admit she loved. It was a map of Andover without names. It had the streets. It had the curve of the river and the mistakes the builders had made and never told anyone. It had the rooflines like a deck of cards laid wrong. It had no Margaret’s, no Daniel’s, no Mr. Crisp, no Hester, no Magdalene. At the bottom, in a hand that did not belong to printing and did not care, was written: There. Is that better.

Elias put his hand against the glass and felt the shape of a man’s satisfaction on the other side like the heat of a kettle you’ve set to boiling and forgotten until it sings. He did not break the window, not because he could not have but because he had not brought a broom. He said the names to the pane. The glass fogged. The map did not take them. It did not listen. It was, after all, not a thing but an idea about a thing. He lowered his hand. He looked at the sky, which had got on with its own business and was pulling its dark up over one knee like a girl with a ladder in her stocking. He stood until he came away cold.

That night the town dreamed of turning left at One and finding Hester’s pocket mirror hung in a hedge to tell you which way was west and making a face at it because it would not get to be that sort of authority. Elias slept on his side with Quill between his chest and his bent knees, the cat a warm, earnestly purring comma. In the drawer with the spoons, a tiny amount of cat hair collected on the silver handles, which made Elias smile in his sleep without knowing why. The ribbon over the pamphlets held, and the pamphlets sulked and imagined a future in which they would be framed and taken out at bedtime to frighten adolescents and were disappointed without understanding they were being told their own ending.

In the morning there would be small spoils: Mr. Bobbin’s violin would have learned a tune it had not known; Elijah Grieves would ring the bell a fraction late and not care; Mrs. Hardesty would hand a sausage to a child who had not asked and say That one is on the house and then be unable to stop herself from blushing and scolding to hide how right it felt; Magdalene would find the word lend under her thumb and it would make a small dent in her skin that lasted an hour and reminded her of a time when she had meant to be somebody else and had chosen instead to be exactly what she was and had not, for a single day since, regretted the economy of it. Vellum would draw a new line, straighter, and an old paper boat would give up pretending to float in a bowl that ought to have had soup in it and sink without drama. The dot in Elias’s pocket would sit and sit and at some point he would take it out and set it on the table and it would look like dirt and he would laugh and Quill would consider the laugh and allow it.

He did not write, that night, the thing the letter had asked him to pretend had been written already. He did not retract anything that needed keeping. He put his finger on the list by the broom and wrote in his awful hand rest, and under it wrote rest again, and under it wrote sweep and then drew a line and wrote bread and then put the pencil down because it was only a pencil and men have gone astray with worse and better. He slept and in his sleep his mother came into the room that was a memory and told him not to point because it was rude, and he did, and she laughed, which is how boys survive their mothers’ rules, and then he woke and the day began again in the way days do when you mean to get them right and can’t but will keep trying because you have the words.

8. Errata

Sunday found Andover shining itself up as if for company. The air had the brittle brightness of a glass knocked into light and not yet broken. Men shaved properly; women pinned their hair with the pins they kept for visitors. The bells moved Elijah Grieves the way the river moved a leaf—by habit, by love, by something older than either—and the first sound they made was almost right and then right because the town had decided to let it be. Elias woke before the bells. He lay still and listened to the house think about him. It had decided he was not a bad bargain. Quill, who had slept hard as a comma wedged between two clauses, stretched up the length of Elias’s ribs and yawned in his face with a breath like chamomile and old sarcasm.

“They’ll have printed God by now,” Quill remarked, as if the information could be taken or left without consequence. “Tiny and neat. He’ll hand Him around on cards with a piece of string. Men will wear Him in their hats.”

“If He takes offense,” Elias said, “He’ll have to stand in line.” He sat and put his feet on the floor and felt the ache that spoke east last night, west at dusk, declare itself a new compass point that existed only for this day: inwards, under the breastbone, where old promises rest. He dressed without thinking and came out odd and then even, which happens when the hands have known the day’s shape and the mind has not caught up. On the back of the chair hung the scarf he had not straightened. He grinned at it for having chosen sides.

The vicar, who was only sometimes a man and more often a question with his collar on, knocked at Elias’s door with an embarrassment he had not been born with. Elias admired men who had acquired embarrassments as you admire men who have acquired skills late by hard practice. “Elias,” the vicar said, leaning in with his hat in both hands like a penitent, “before you come—if you do come—there’s a thing I should say. Someone’s put a paper. On the pulpit. It has notes for my sermon I didn’t write. I’m not sure what I’m supposed to do about it. They’re proper notes. Footnotes. With little numbers.”

“Take the numbers off,” Elias said kindly. He did not mean from the speech; he meant from the man. He reached for the vicar’s fingers, which had hymnal dust in the creases, and put a thumb into the seam of his hand and rubbed until the skin remembered itself as skin and not paper. “If the words on the slip ask you to say ‘deliver us from discomfort’ instead of ‘deliver us from evil,’ take it as a suggestion from a person who cannot tell one from the other. And under no circumstances let the notes tell people to sit through the bit they should stand for.”

The vicar laughed unhappily. His laugh had a gap in it where a tooth had gone when he was twelve, running and not looking, and some part of him had never forgiven the lane. “You make it sound easy,” he said.

“I make it sound plain,” Elias returned. “Come to my step when you are done and shake your hands out. The rope left numbers on them yesterday. We must not let prayers do the same. They have enough to answer for without arithmetic.”

The church had put itself together with a stern prettiness that always made Elias think of girls being told to remember which fork. The memorial tablets along the nave had been polished to a better self and glowed. The whole place smelled of beeswax, starch, men’s necks and women’s patience. Elias went in at the back because cats do not love being made to choose between a cushion and a knee, and Quill had opinions about velvet. He trotted along the pew tops like a baron inspecting property and leaped to a beam where he could look pious without blasphemy.

People filled the wooden pens by household habit rather than God’s governance. Mrs. Hardesty balanced piety with her shop, head up as if to dare the Lord to mind her sausages. Mr. Bobbin had brought his fiddle in its case with him because he did not trust the house to leave it alone; he held it like a child he would have wanted without believing he deserved. Hester Stowe slid between her mother and Mrs. Troon with the baby and produced her stolen mirror, which she hung by its rough edge on the hook where hymn numbers should go and then covered with a handkerchief because even a vain thing may serve if humiliated into humility. Magdalene Plum sat with her hands folded like a woman whose palms have not been without ink for twenty years. She had washed them. The ink had considered and stayed.

On the pulpit lay the paper. It had a look that wanted to be official without the authority to be so, the way a boy in his father’s hat looks like a jest unless you love him. The vicar glanced at it and put both hands on the edges as if to hold it to one side of the sermon as you would a naughty child in a crowd. He began with the words no one remembered having decided were the right ones to begin with, and the hush, which had been crouched in the rafters peering down into everyone’s throats, slid itself to the edge to listen.

The footnotes waited. They were printed in such a respectful type that if you squinted you might be moved to admire the authority even as it began its insults. At the bottom of the page a number 1 asked him to add ‘for those of us who do not dabble’ after the prayer for those who go out into the town to serve. A small 2 wanted him to replace the word wicked with wayward. Number 3 was giddy with its own cleverness; it had a Latin phrase that meant nothing in Latin and was meant to make the men feel that their tongues had chosen a side. The vicar cleared his throat and chose to be poor in Latin that day. He used wicked and meant it. He came to the prayer for the town and its water, and the hush leaned very hard and tried to keep him from saying river, and he took a breath and said Anton with his mouth open as if he were asking a question and the bell above heard and answered it.

Elias felt the sting of something sly in the beam. He lifted his face. Along the memorial tablets, the big ones for men who had made the town applaud them and the little ones for boys who had not done themselves the good or harm of living long, there ran a faint shadow like thin smoke. It was not smoke. It was an eraser in a good suit. It took the tiny raised serif off Elijah Grieves’s dead son’s name and made it look misspelled, then thought better and put a number beside it as if the boy had been a note to the line. On the tablet to Mrs. Bell’s mother, who had delivered half of Andover and had died in a chair by the fire with her apron on because she had not meant to go yet, the word mother flickered and wanted to be matron, and then midwife, and then attendant, and then nothing, only a space where a woman might stand unnoticed all her life and the town would only think to praise the floor once it had gone.

Elias moved into the aisle without asking the aisle’s leave. The vicar faltered and then did not because the thing in his hands felt the weight of a man walking with intent and did not wish to be laughed at for its hollowness. Elias laid his palm on the bottom right of Mrs. Bell’s mother’s brass and felt the shape of the name that was not up but under. He had no right to be here without being family. He was family by use. He said the woman’s name under his breath and under his breath there was the ribbon round a hair and the way she had said Now, girl, breathe, which is the way men should have been taught to enter rooms all their lives. The brass warmed under his hand. It took patience to coax good truth from metal; metal has been told what to be for so long it forgets it can ring when it is asked correctly. He did not press. He waited. Under his fingers, the faint, fidgeting desire to be official gave up, and the word mother deepened its groove.

Quill, up on his beam, clawed at a thin nothing that had caught on one of his whiskers. He pinned it to the wood and read it with distaste. “Errata,” he said under his breath, and a boy three rows back who had come because his mother had insisted and meant to count how many nails were in the pew in front of him tasted the word and had to spit into his handkerchief because his mouth was not made to carry such sourness with silence.

It moved fast when you watched where it tried to be slow. On the memorial for Elijah’s son, the number softened, then ran. Elias smudged it with his thumb deliberately and put a dot where it had been without writing it and it sat, prim as an aunt expecting cake, and made the place where the mischief had been feel finished in a way that nothing nasty can stand. He went as a man goes along benches when he must leave in a hurry, touching, not stopping. He put a hand on the stone for the man who had funded the school and taken the money back and died anyway and said, not kindly, not unkindly, “Your wife is not short for your achievement.” The stone did not argue; it did not, in fairness, have a leg to stand on.

When the prayer was done and the footnotes had sulked themselves into quiet ink, the vicar shut the book. He saw Elias in the aisle and looked briefly like a man offered a bowl just when his hands have learned to carry three plates. He made a face that warned the footnotes he might collect offerings with his head up and the footnotes whispered in affront about proper liceity and collapsed into their own type. The hymn after, an innocuous one about wheat, went like it always does in towns where people have seen famine from the wrong end: tentative, then full, then soft at the last line where the simile comes and makes you cry in front of your neighbors if you’re not careful. The hush tried to sing and choked on its own breath. It took itself away to sulk in the vestry. The footnotes tried to get people’s attention in the lane and no one read them because dinners had been put on and timing is a magic as good as any.

As they came out into the sharp midday, Elijah Grieves put both hands into Elias’s and made the face of a man who has dropped a weight of steel and been handed a bag of flour in its place. “He had rounded my boy off,” he said. “Thought to make him cleaner by taking off what his letters had. Thank you.” His gratitude had no bow on it. It was meat. Elias took it and swallowed and did not think of Vellum’s soup.

On the path, the vicar shook his hands as instructed and made a little breath like a boy told well done for something he did not know he had done and wanted to claim with both fists. “There was a note,” he said, not ashamed. “At the bottom of the page, after If there are any who are to be present in the holy estate of matrimony. It said, instead of Speak now or forever hold your peace, it suggested the phrase Speak now or apply at the office. I may have said something rude under my breath. God will forgive me.” He looked sideways the way men do before they say a thing they are afraid makes them sound weak. “If he writes my mother on a card,” he added, “I shall not read the card aloud. Is that permitted.”

“It is required,” Elias said. “You must not let a stranger put your mother where everyone can see her for the first time.” He had to leave then because his chest had been pierced by a fool with thin ink who could not have known where to aim; the word mother had laid itself against his ribs with a weight like wet wool.

Back on his step he found a boy had been. The boy had hands that shook as if he had made a choice against supervision. He had left a thing that did not look like Vellum’s at all. It had been written in a crabbed hand on a scrap cut ragged with a table knife. It said Sorry I helped and under it, in a handwriting older than his, was written I know. Elias put his hand on his table. It was steady enough. He put the scrap under the ribbon as if he were teaching two words to lie down together and not mate. Quill leaped up beside it and looked away because when cats grant privacy to paper, men should do the same.

Errata slips came heavy as flies after that, on plates, on tins, in pockets. Mrs. Hardesty reached into her apron and found one that said, in the small voice that always knows best, butcheress and she snarled and threw it in the fat and the fat popped as if you had insulted a woman who had been very good this morning and did not deserve it. Mamie Coppin lifted her teapot and discovered the word mean where steam should be and she put in a bay leaf and told the cleverness to steep, and it became the color of an old bruise and swam to the top and she skimmed it off and sprinkled it on the geranium, which surprised everyone by surviving.

The worst of it came not to a woman used to argument and knives, nor to a man who had practiced saying no and yes in public, but to Mrs. Bell, the midwife. She met Elias on the corner by the shop with a bundle of paper in her apron and her face arranged very neatly, which is what grief does when it has a job. “He has a list,” she said without preface. “Not my list. I keep the names of babies. It makes their first morning heavier so they don’t blow away. He has cut mine up and put mine on cards with spaces where his pen has not been and he has made a binder. He will bring it as a gift when a woman goes hard in her labor. He thinks he is being modern.”

Elias took the bundle from her without the ceremony his hands wanted because ceremony would have put a lace cap on madness. He sat on the stoop of the abandoned shop that had never kept a grocer long because it liked to be empty and spread the spoiled names on his knees like a fortune-teller with cards she does not trust. The paper had not been torn; it had been clipped with a precision that meant to be flattering and failed. The names had been put into a new order. Not order by the day and the evening and the two a.m. that had required Mrs. Bell to put on her boots and go out in a nightgown and her shawl. This order was by weight and color and whether the father had signed. Numbers had crept up the margins like damp. In a neat hand that had pleased Magdalene once on an invoice a year ago and displeased her now by association was written Above Average, and after it a list of boys; Below Average, and after it a list that had girls in it like thunder.

Mrs. Bell breathed as women do when they have been told to be polite in other people’s tragedy and have decided they would be and still mean to kill, later, with a kindness. “If I go and cut his paper up,” she said, “it will make another boy that boy and he will become the sort who makes lists. I would rather break his thumb.”

“Strings first,” Elias said. He stacked the cleverness and pulled the long loop of hair-ribbon from his pocket. It would not be enough; ribbons never are. He had a spool of twine in his bag and felt for it without looking, a man who always knows where his own thread is. He tied the cards back into bundles where the names had belonged. He did not do it well. He did it twice and then again and the third time the knot sat properly and sulked. “Keep yours in a box under your bed,” he told Mrs. Bell. “Put a kettle on top. If a man with a binder comes, we will rearrange his fingers into a new order.”

Mrs. Bell laughed in the soundless way that means a woman has decided not to let crying take up space it cannot pay for. “I will tell her to breathe,” she said. “And I will tell her that knowing the word under the word is the only thing that makes a birth go right.” She touched Elias’s sleeve. It was not gratitude. It was exactly this: a midwife leaving some truth she could not fit in her pockets on a man’s arm because she had to go and could not take it with her.

By midafternoon, the list-making had turned to maps again. The signs staked in the fields had multiplied in the night like a complaint that catches; a new one stood at the gap to the path where boys went to avoid being seen going to smoke. FIELD 1. PARCEL 5. The words sat neat on metal and made the hedge look guilty for having grown with its own shape instead of any square. Hester had her hands in her pockets and a pebble in her mouth to keep from saying things the vicar would borrow and put in a sermon and not return. “He’s making a game,” she said, her eyes hot because injustice made her cry not like a girl, like Hester. “He thinks we’ll forget our names and be grateful when he gives us numbers to pin to them as if they were clean shirts.”

“We will make him play something stupid,” Elias said. He had a child’s comfort in the foolish. “Hopscotch,” he added, because remembrance has squares in it, too, and a thrown stone and a rule about stepping where you shouldn’t. He chalked nine boxes on the green where chalk had lately been idolatrous and not been liked for it, and the action pleased him for its insolence. In the first he put the word here. In the second, the word now. In the third, the word bread. In the fourth and fifth, he put two small drawings like those Hester made when she was meant to be following sums; one of a cat, haughty as a mayor, one of a bell. In the sixth, he left it empty because not everything needs to be said to be counted. In the seventh and eighth he put the words speak and listen. In the ninth he wrote stay.

Hester watched him as if gathering new techniques for warfare to be employed at kitchen tables when you are too short to be impressive. “You’ve made a game out of words,” she said.

“I’ve made words into a game,” he corrected. “Jump.” She jumped, and the stone he had set to throw—a small, smooth thing you would have kept in your pocket after finding it for years—landed on listen and obliged her to skip with her mouth shut, which nearly killed her and made her grin as if she had invented discipline. The green liked it. The green always liked it when games were played with fairness and the right amount of cheating and no bets that meant dusk took more than the afternoon had given.

Vellum, meanwhile, sat in the below-room with the window that made the light look like water trying to be useful in a bucket and drew a line he thought might please someone he had never met and never would. He had not slept. He did not look like a man who had not slept. He looked like a word that had been kept out of a sentence and would not forgive the omission. The crow, which was not a bird but had the habit of one the way a door has the habit of opening, sat on the press and made small motions with its beak as if pins were a delicacy and it had acquired a taste for them at someone else’s expense. Vellum wrote in the margin of the map the words: it will be easier, then struck out easier and wrote better and then struck out better and wrote necessary and did not notice that his hand shook because there are tremblings that have nothing to do with cold.

When he sent the next thing, he was too clever by half. He had discovered an old trick: errata not in the present but in the past. He slid thin slips into the parish register where the births were and the deaths and the little line that read baptised and the long line that read illegitimate which had been put there by a man fifty years ago who could not bear to have his theology contradicted by biology and so wrote it down and felt tidy. The slips were so convincing that if you did not know a thing you would swallow them whole and not know it; they did not look like additions, they looked like just the way it had been all along. Mr. Bobbin, who had been told all his life he had hands for iron and never for catgut, went to the book and found a note beneath his baptism written in a small hand and a smaller voice: not musical. It made his wrists cold. Mrs. Hardesty found that her mother’s death had been attributed to intemperance when it had been a fever as ordinary and as deadly as any and she swore aloud in the church because there are decencies and then there are decencies.

Elias went through the side door with Quill in his bag because not even God was going to keep him out with ink in the rafters. The clerk had the sort of scar between his eyebrows that had been a wrinkle once and then hardened into proof he had tried to use his face to think for too long. He looked at Elias as if to say this is not your province. Elias laid his hand on the book as if it were a cat. He did not flip past the flyleaf, which had its own ideas about being valuable. He turned pages until he came to his own mother’s name and he stopped because the book knew how to make him do that. He had not done this before. He had not let anyone too tidy put their finger near it. He read the line. He read the neat hand that was not the vicar’s of the time and not any hand he knew and he read the small word at the edge in the new ink and the word said away and it had not been written by God.

“No,” Elias told it. He did not speak to the book. He spoke to the paper put on the paper. He touched his pocket where the period had sat all morning and had decided to live there the way some animals decide on a particular rock. He lifted it out and set it at the edge of the page, not on the terrible word, near it, like a bowl set near a drunk man, ready. “You have put an end where there was a gap,” he said softly. “I will not allow that.” He slid the dot over the away, and it did not smear; it sat and stared at the additive until it looked like a stranger in a kitchen at night. The extra letters, which had thought to be indispensable as a teaspoon, found they had only been the gleam on one. They went flat. He moved the dot back and left the place clean and raw as it had always been. “I know what away means,” he said to no one and to everyone. “It does not mean gone.”

The clerk, who had not the habit of weeping because his father had told him it was a thing men paid women to do, wiped his nose with his sleeve and let himself feel as if he had found a coin in a pocket he had sewed up himself. “I didn’t know one could argue with these,” he admitted, astonished to hear his voice casual as bread in his own mouth.

“You can,” Elias said. “They lie if you don’t.” He took the pen, because you are allowed to take a pen if your fingers know how to hold a child by the ankle and check for splinters, and wrote in the margin in his poor hand very small the words checked, and under them, in smaller, the truth as a thing held between two people and not printed. He did not make a sermon of it. He made a note to himself with a witness. He laid the ribbon he had been allowed across the page the way a woman lays a washcloth on a fevered head. The paper sighed without rustle. It is embarrassing, sometimes, to be saved.

When he came out into the yard, he spoke to the town because he would have had to go home otherwise and sit with tea and the door and the ache and he could not yet. He stood by the chestnut, which had known three generations of boys by their knife marks and had resigned itself to a life of scars. “Say your names,” he said to the people going by with their yawns and their plans. “First and last and middle if you have one. Say the ones you don’t use. Say the ones your grandmother called you that nobody would let you write. Say the ones you made up and never told anyone because you were eight and thought you’d be someone else. Say them aloud, in order, and then go buy onions.” It was absurd. It was a man putting a cup into the hands of a storm and asking it to pour. It worked because it was absurd. Magdalene said Magdalene Eunice Plum without blush and the town heard Eunice and stored it where it keeps lace. Mr. Bobbin said Tobias and then Bobbin and then in a small voice the name his wife had not been allowed to put on the stone and the stone in his chest shifted to make room. Mrs. Hardesty said Jane like a door shutting properly and felt the weight of the truth of a small name. Hester put her hands in her pockets and said Hester Hester Hester and then added Stowe as if it were her own idea and the men who named things glanced reluctantly down and had to write it.

By late afternoon the map in the school window had acquired names it had not intended to. Someone with a less neat hand and a better idea of the town had chalked Daniel’s Oat across Field 2 and drawn an arrow meaning that definitely includes the hedge and if you don’t like it you can climb it. Someone else had put Margaret’s Drop where it belonged and added in the margin, mind the ditch, and a third, perhaps Hester, perhaps a boy she would shortly marry or fight, had written The Square With The Hole In It and drawn an indelicate picture beside it that made Vellum smile and then hate himself for smiling. The not-crow pecked at the chalk marks and came away with grit on its tongue and sulked because pins were sweeter.

At dusk, when respectable towns begin to be their less respectable selves and respectable men their more, the errata slowed. There is only so much correction one mind can pay attention to in a day. There are only so many polite cruelties you can display before the thin satisfaction of them leaks out and you remember you have soups to eat.
