Vellum sat with his hand on the press and looked at the painted soldier that had nothing to do with anything and everything to do with the boy who had been told not to point. He put his finger out and touched it and hated himself so thoroughly for the longing that the hate made a mark on his skin. He wrote a short letter, the sort that makes a man late for his dinner because he wants the sound of the words and not the sense. It said: Make a bargain with me. It said: I will take your mother out of my mouth if you take your town out of yours. It said: you do not know how to be quiet. He did not send it. He tore it up into pieces so small even a crow with pins for a palate would not bother.

Elias, who had said names until his tongue went woolly and did not mind, sat on his step and ate bread with jam and a ridiculous peace in it. Quill lay with his front paws straight and his back paws ridiculous and watched a fly with admiration for its adherence to its own brief. Hester came with her mirror and her head up like a girl who has decided not to audition for the parts she is offered and sat without being asked and without being trouble. “What will he do next,” she demanded, taking a bite of bread as if she meant to bite a sentence.

“He will send numbers to charity,” Elias said. “He will ration kindness. He will issue tickets for grief. He will say how many tears are appropriate per day, per death, per season. He will make goodness into something you line up for and resent.”

“And we will not,” Hester said, not as question and not as boast. She had learned already to take the day by the scruff. “What will we do.”

“We will hang the verbs by the pump,” Elias said. “We will say the names already in our mouths. We will write small notes in books that look like God. We will lay ribbons on paper. We will drink when it is time and go on speaking when the hush sits down and we will sing ill and well. We will take the pins out of things that ought to keep their motion. We will be ridiculous enough that cleverness sulks and goes to bed without supper.”

“Will we win,” Hester asked, as if you could ask a question like that and have it be treated with all the seriousness in the world and all the flippancy too.

“We will not lose in ways that please him,” Elias said. The dark came up the lane with its hands in its pockets like a boy. It stood at the end of the street and watched him and did nothing to him that he had not invited. “And we will know where the tea is kept.”

Quill, who had made a profession of disdain for vows and a vocation of keeping them, put his chin on Elias’s knee and made a sound like milk boiling, which is how some cats purr when they do not want you to know. He lifted his head a little and added, as if it were a detraction and not a benediction, “You should sleep. Tomorrow he will do something very boring and we will have to be clever against boredom, which is the most dangerous of enemies.”

Elias tipped his head back against the door and looked at the sky, which had unhelpfully not arranged itself to show him which way to choose. He had, of late, stopped believing the sky was meant to instruct him and gone back to asking the floor. The floor had said sweep and he had done what he was told. He stood and closed the door and set the kettle where it belonged and wrote on the list on the back of his door the word mend, and under it, the word rest, and found that if you put them together they make the little sound you hear when a woman sits down and does not yet get up.

He slept with the dot on the table and not in his pocket because you must teach magic to trust the furniture, which is where life lives. Vellum dreamed of a field with no names and woke with the taste of someone else’s hunger in his mouth and stood with his hand on the press until the metal cooled and remembered it was iron and not a question. The river turned under the bridge and looked up at the sky and decided it would not be taking anyone today without asking, and the town replied with the disagreeable contentment of a house that has been cleaned and will be dirty again in a minute, and both facts can be borne.

10. Allowances

Monday woke like a book that had been put back on the shelf with a leaf inside, saving someone’s place, and the leaf had learned to read in the dark and had things to report. The low air had the starch of laundries about it, as if the sky had ironed itself and then forgotten what shape men wanted. Elias did not mind a dressed day when he had time to undress it gently, but he had slept with the dot on the table and it had rolled against his fingers twice in the night as if it were a chick or a headache, and he knew that the business of undoing would begin before his tea. Quill had taken the liberty of being both tender and rude in his sleep; he had rearranged himself across Elias’s ribs like a punctuation mark with legal opinions and woken him twice by sneezing, which a cat will do if it believes the air has intruded on its person. When Elias swung his feet to the floor, the house shook itself as a settled bird does, not displeased to discover it still had its man.

They brought them in baskets the color of the postman’s temper on wet days, and they were stamped with a crown and a seal and a line that claimed legality the way a child claims a pebble and expects everyone to agree the whole beach is his. Coupons, people said without being taught to, and they were right and wrong, right because the paper had been cut by a hard mind into small useful shreds, wrong because usefulness does not always sit in pieces. The books were blue, but not the kind that comforts; they had the sadness of ledgers and the creak of swings under grown men. Inside were neat perforations, and on each perforation in a hand that had meant to be merciful was printed a kindness. One read: two minutes of sympathy, transferable. Another: one listening, uninterrupting, may be redeemed on Tuesdays and Thursdays at the convenience of the listener. There were strips for patience and for civility and for the thing a man says when a child breaks a plate and he decides not to teach with a shout, and at the back, in a pocket that made Mrs. Hardesty’s left eye twitch as if it had remembered ration books and the way hunger looks in the mirror, there were Special Allowances: three for grief, one for wild joy, one for rage if used with precautions and an adult present.

They came with people who had never taken a penny from a hand that did not wish to give one. Good men brought them and women with proper collars and a girl with a nervous lip who had learned to clench it between words and now could not let it go. “To avoid abuse,” these people said, and their voices had the glaze of meetings on them, and they held out the books with both hands like wafers. “So that everyone has a share. So that the generous are not made destitute. So that the loud do not take all the air.” For a minute in and among the geese on the green and the voices of men going to their Monday and the smell of cheap soap trying to be lemon, the town listened as if it were possible to put a bit of fairness into a pocket and not have it cut a hole on the way in.

By ten, Hester had already tried to buy a sorry with a patience and been told that the exchange rate was set in a printed notice and would she please not be sarcastic until after noon. She put both hands in her pockets and told the woman with the notice—who was Mrs. Cray, who had never been in charge of anything but her hair and was doing badly by it—that she would prefer to be sarcastic before noon because the light then was better. Elias took a book from the timid boy who had brought it and looked at it like a man making himself admire a hat a neighbor had made. He turned the pages and did not touch the perforations, because things with teeth in their edges like to be fed. Quill ran a whisker down the spine and sneezed again because sincerity in ink had always brought on a mild allergy.

“It is a clever cruelty,” Quill said finally, as if he was granting a rival the compliment of a nod across a battlefield. “He has made kindness into a cupboard. He will ration the cups. He will say who washes them. He will make a schedule and when a man is late for his civility, he will be fined.”

“We will be poorer if we count it,” Elias said. He put the book on the table and did the impolite thing; he wrote in his own hand through the printed word. He made loops and they were not tidy loops and Magdalene would have thrown a rag at him for the blot, but it was his and it said on the inside cover: you cannot keep soup with pins. He went out with the book in his pocket because you must learn the shape of a weapon before you teach people to ignore it. On the threshold, he touched the lintel and told the house he might be late to his noon, and the house held its breath and then let it go with an audible patience that struck him as indecently moving.

The queue had already formed by the pump. It did not know it was a queue; it thought it was a group of people all of whom had happened to think of water at the same time, which is what queues pretend when they are in fields and not in offices. A man stood at the head of it with the kind of authority that men take up when the sash is handed to them and they do not look at the sash closely enough to see the moth holes. He had a pin in his lapel and a notebook with a ribbon and a brass pencil that made him very happy in a way that did not want to be considered vulgar and was. “Kindnesses,” he said into the air as if someone had asked what time the train goes, “are to be requested with the coupon attached. The volunteer with the kettle may redeem and initial. No more than one wild joy per day per family. Exceptions by special application.” He wore an expression that was aiming for benign and could not settle there, the way a wasp will aim for jam but the jam has a skin on.

Short John stood behind him with his hands hanging like two question marks and no answers. He had on a sash he had not been born to and his face was pale in the way faces go pale when a boy is praised for something that has not grown in the soil of him. In his pocket were more books and he jostled them with a knee in a way that told Elias, who knew pockets like a man knows the mouths of kettles, that Short John knew he ought not be where he was. He caught Elias’s eye with the desperate dignity of a child caught playing king; he did not blush, because that would have given the game away, and the lack of blush made Elias want to put his hand on the back of the boy’s neck in a way nobody would like.

Mrs. Troon came with the baby who had a Tuesday in him and a foot that liked water and exercised more caution than anyone thought. She handed over a coupon: one sympathy, good for five minutes, valid this week only. The man with the brass pencil took it between finger and thumb and held it up to the light as if sorrys have watermarks, and he inclined his head and wrote Mrs. Troon on a line with a little flourish that meant I am paid for doing this by admiration, and Magdalene appeared at his left shoulder with a look that suggested she would like to take that flourish and feed it to him. “No,” she said very politely, which is a word that tells men to stop or the tea will be spilled on their pants. “You will go to my shop. You will sit on my stool. You will count this in ink until ink refuses to be counted. Leave my pump alone.”

“It is for equitable distribution,” the man said, with the haughtiness of someone who has read a pamphlet about equity. “We must ensure that the town is not prey to the generous. We must ensure that certain people do not take advantage.” He glanced by accident toward Hester and then looked very quickly away, as if her face had a habit of pulling the meanings off sentences and he did not wish to be stripped in public. Hester grinned because she had done just that.

Elias took the man’s notebook from his carefully correct hands and looked at the ribbon. It had been chosen by a woman; it had learned the shape of her fingers and was ashamed of its work. “I have a ledger for you,” he said, because you must always offer to rehome a thing that is being misused before you burn it. “It is on a wide table. It has a bowl of small apples beside it. It is called the commons. You do not write in anyone’s column. You write in your own. Each day you write what you have taken and what you have brought. You write forgive myself for not bringing soup on Thursday to Mrs. Hardesty and then you bring her a sausage on Friday because she has not eaten, and then you write the kind of truth that makes your hands good, for instance I told a lie about my neighbor’s daughter to see if my tongue still worked, and it did, and I would like to trade that for two hours of sweeping. You do it because your hands know it is right, not because I initial.”

“No initialing,” Magdalene confirmed, sweet and deadly. “No ribbons. No brass pencils. No hats. You may use a burnt stick and the back of your hand if you must, so long as you wash after.” She looked over the man’s shoulder and saw the long morning where he had been taught to earn his keep by preventing other people from becoming less precise, and her mouth softened very slightly because she was not cruel and because a woman with a press knows where to set and where to let go.

The pump insisted upon its own say in the matter, being a democratic sort of iron. It had drunk water for forty years and spit it back with dignity for almost as long, and it would not be told when to be generous by a booklet with perforations. Elias wrapped Magdalene’s wet list of verbs around the handle. He took Quill’s actually from yesterday and stuck it with a fingernail to the man’s lapel, because there are insects it is rude not to return when someone has brought them to a gathering. Then he stood back and let Mrs. Troon put her cup under the fall as if she had done it when she was a girl, because she had. The groan in the pump’s first stroke went down into the ground and woke the good idea that had been sleeping under the green since someone decided to lay it flat and call it a place where a man can show off his potatoes. It made a sound that said we do not tear kindness into tickets, we keep it in bowls.

Vellum, who had expected barter and rage and a crowd of the unfairly sanctimonious, was disappointed by bowls. He put his pen down on the press and then picked it up again because he never put his pen down; it had grown into his hand in little roots and would have had to be dug out. He had thought to make them tidy, to make them say please in the right places and thank you where it would be counted and admitted into the ledger of what you can show to your sons. He had thought they would line up for sympathy the way they line up for meat. The paper breathed out on the press when he leaned over it as if it were a woman under a man that she had not chosen; it was an indrawn breath as thin as the edge of a knife. He smiled because he had made men behave well by compulsion and that is the oldest pleasure of a certain sort of mind, and then he frowned because fields with names were being written on his map by hands that did not ask permission. He did not ask the crow to go and tear them down because he did not like to ask, and in that small habit, which had begun as a point of pride and turned into a disability, there was a piece of his undoing.

The inspectors wore sashes, as Quill had predicted, which is the same as tying a ribbon around someone’s hunger and expecting them to get full. They came to doors and asked people to show their books and their allotment of civility and any special permits for sympathy offered beyond the ordinary allotment, and they had lists in which generous women had been recorded with a tick in the margin that meant caution and perhaps a complaint later. Mr. Crisp’s daughter, whose name was Eliza and whose father had persistently attempted to make it Lizzie because he thought that would make her kinder and had been surprised when it did not, came to the step with neither hat nor apology and asked which inspector wanted to come inside and untangle the string she kept for tying parcels. When no one volunteered, she put her hands behind her back and spoke as if she were a catechism and you had better get the answers right. “No,” she said with proper elevation, “you may not count my decency. It does not fit in your boxes. Also, I will have back the paper you handed to the boy this morning that told him his kindness was to be administered by others, as I have told that boy since he was a wall-nibbler that he could choose when to say yes and no, and I will not have you take my teaching and make a ledger of it.”

Short John, who had been invited to memorise and had discovered memory was not improved by having your name shortened by a man with a pin, handed her his own book without meaning to. His hand had gone out because he remembered being offered sugar on a spoon and he had remembered that there are days when you want to feed someone even if it makes your mother cross. Eliza took it and tore the cover off very neatly and gave him the pages intact and he stood blinking at the niceness of the mercy as if it were rain that did not wet you, and then the torn cover lying in her palm showed its inside, full of the words of instructions men never read after the first pride, and Eliza looked at the tiny print and hated it with a cold precision that Elias would remember for a long time when he needed to aim at a hinge.

“I will take that,” Elias said, because he did not want Eliza to poison herself on contempt and spend the morning vomiting where it would do no good. He tucked the cover into his pocket with the dot and the truth card and the ribbon and felt as if he were walking around with a woman’s reticule in his trousers, which tickled him and kept him from making a speech. He did not make a speech because Quill had warned him that the enemy today lay with boredom. “Collect your cups,” he said instead, and the town did because a habit had begun in them and neither Vellum’s cleverness nor anyone’s weariness had had time to stop it. People brought out the chipped ones and the ridiculous ones, the cups with praise printed on them for jubilees not their own and the one without a handle that a grandfather would not part with because his hand had decided where to hold, and they set them on the table that Magdalene and Mr. Bobbin had brought out, which was the one that had never liked to live indoors and had longed for a market all its life and had been obliged to be respectable. On the table was laid a cloth that did not match anything and therefore matched the town.

They wrote, not in the blue books, but on paper that had wrapped a ham and on the back of a notice about Methodist teas and on one page of the Hampshire Chronicle that had got loose from binding because Magdalene had let it go. They wrote what they brought: I will come and sit at your window and say nothing on Wednesday. They wrote what they needed: my husband will not speak to me because the Queen died and he thinks being sad must be bigger than a kitchen and I would like someone to tell him the kitchen can hold the Queen if you open the doors. They wrote in ugly hands and in beautiful ones and in a child’s block capitals, and Eliza wrote a note that said, as if daring someone to disagree, I am very bad at funerals; I can carry chairs. The list of verbs began to pick up in its fibers a new category of action that had not been set in type and probably never would be because the world would not consider it decent: the work of listening while someone fails to tell the truth and forgives himself.

That afternoon, when it would have been a pretty cruelty to do nothing and watch a town exhaust itself on its own virtue, Vellum sent the inspectors to the church. They came with a ledger that asked Elijah Grieves to account for how many bells had been rung for how many griefs and whether the bells had resounded equally for the rich and the eating of sausages yesterday, and Elijah took the book in both hands and regarded it as if it were a coal shovel asking to be consulted on weddings. He set it down. He wrote in a hand so slow and exact that any inspector would be obliged to watch until boredom did what truth could not, and he wrote: the bell rings the same for anyone who held a spoon. Then he added: the bell rings the same for anyone who did not, and he underlined did not because he understood that grief sometimes has nothing to do with having had a thing and much to do with having been promised and never given.

Quill, who had no respect for ledgers and a professional interest in paper that presumed, leaped onto an inspector’s lap and placed both paws squarely on the word appropriation before the man could read it, and stayed there until his full cat weight pressed it through the paper and into the man’s trousers as a little shame. The inspector tried to move him and could not because there are laws in this world that only cats enforce, and finally he laughed helplessly and let the laughing go on two seconds longer than he should have because it was not the tone pamphlets require. When he stood up at last, the word had transferred to his shirt and he would have to go home before he could be seen enforcing anything else, and this, too, was a mercy the town pretended not to understand.

For his countercharm, Elias did not bring a broom because brooms would offend men who believed in ledgers; he brought a ledger bigger than theirs. He took the book Mrs. Bell kept under her bed and carried the kettle on top of it the way he had told her to, and he laid it on the commons table open at the page where the babies’ names had been rearranged in Vellum’s pretty formation and straightened again with twine. “Write your own kindnesses to yourselves,” he said, and the town looked at him as if he had suggested that men put their hands in their own pockets and share out their money to the person who always forgot he deserved any. He nodded at Mr. Crisp’s daughter because he was not above calling in a terror when he needed one, and Eliza wrote at the top of a clean page with the printshop’s ugly pen in an ugly ink: I forgive myself for not liking funerals, as long as I carry chairs, and she signed it, and the ink looked better at once for having been given a bad job to do and doing it with an honest back.

He made a thing with string and spoons, because words are not everything and metal is next to truth if you ask the right question. He took spoons, which were the same spoons men have argued over for a thousand years, and he tied string to them, and he laid them in a bowl in the center of the table, and he told anyone who came to the commons that if they left without taking one, he would be cross. Hester took a spoon, because Hester would take anything that looked as if it might become a weapon later, and she put it in her pocket and made it ring when she walked. Mr. Bobbin tied his string around his wrist because he did not trust himself to keep hold of things that were not heavy. Mrs. Hardesty put hers under the counter because she had a way of reaching for sharp words and she wanted to grab metal first. The spoons knocked together when the wind came, and the sound they made was the kind of small music that rearranges a miser into a person who remembers that the spoon in his hand is meant for soup he intends to share.

Vellum tried boring them in the afternoon, because Quill had predicted boredom, and a man will always try the tactic you least fear when he thinks you’ve become clever. He sent a procession. It was not the sort of procession that makes boys throw their caps and girls adjust their collars; it was the sort of procession that a man invents when he has never been celebrated and suspects that celebration is a punishment. They came with white bands around their arms and white cloths tied to sticks and white feathers on their hats that made their hats look ashamed, and they walked without a band and without a stride and without anything to carry properly and they asked that people admire the Quiet. They did not speak. They did not sing. They did not shuffle. They were the kind of silence that wave at windows and wait to be invited in to sit on chairs and tell women their grief is untidy.

Elias did not tell Hester she must not do what she was thinking. He let her run into the back of the procession with bells tied to her ankles, because Hester had learned from Elijah Grieves that bells belong to wrists and rope and people, not to schedules, and she made a noise like a baby storm and the white hats bobbed in agitation like mushrooms in uncertain weather. Mr. Bobbin, whose instrument does not take to being asked for high-mindedness, took out his fiddle and played badly on purpose because badness is sometimes a holy act, and the procession had to step in time to avoid looking ridiculous and then looked ridiculous anyway because a song had attached itself and they had not been made to hold one.

When the white came to the church, the vicar stepped out and spoke to it like a man who had been interrupted while buttering bread. “No,” he said, and he said it with an old west wind in his voice, the kind that knocks apples and leaves them fit for jelly and tells men not to argue about fruit. “You may come in when you have something to carry. We do not admire emptiness on purpose. We admire it by mistake, when we had meant to make soup and the cupboard argued.” The Quiet did not know what to do with being told that it had nothing in its hands. It had been in rooms where being blank earns praise. It had been in rooms where men have made their faces into a refusal to cry and had been congratulated. It had not been in a place where being silent was not a virtue to be paraded but a space to be held while someone else finds her breath.

By late day, the coupons had lost their paper shine and had become merely paper. They were useful to light stoves and to write shopping lists and occasionally to stick under a table leg that wobbled because a man had wished to have his cupboard stand level and the floor refused. Elias took the book from his pocket and tore out the Special Allowance that said for grief, and he went to Mrs. Bell in between calls because he had the offense in his hands and could not carry it another hour, and he laid it on her table and put the kettle on top of it, and he did not speak because there are things you must not say in the presence of a woman whose day keeps people alive. He washed his hands without being asked and took the chair by the stove and scraped his nails carefully with the back of the knife because blood hides in them and you must show it a way out. Mrs. Bell saw him make a ritual and felt, in her elbows, a lessening of something no man had put there. She would not say thank you. She would say breathe to a girl with a long night ahead, and the thank you would be in not dying.

That night, for the first time since he had moved into the lower room, Vellum came up into the air. He did not mean to, which is how you know he was not yet lost to cunning altogether. He brought no paper. He brought the point of his nose and the fragile edge of his pride and stood at the corner where the field with the sign Parcel 7 looked at the hedge and pretended not to be jealous. He looked at the chalk written on his map through the window and at the chalk on the ground that boys had made into boxes with words in them because the big words kept their feet under them when they jumped. He wondered whether he had written the word necessary too many times today and if he had, whether that made it less so. He had known hunger was a bowl you do not talk about; he had not known kindness was a bowl you must talk into or it goes hard on the edges and does not pour.

Elias met him there not because he had guessed at Vellum’s steps but because his own had brought him round the circuit of his day and landed at that corner the way a penny stops because a nail is under the tablecloth. He stood a little way off and did not say “you have come out,” because men who have been under so long think you are mocking them. He stood with his hands in his pockets and thought of his mother’s ribbon and of Short John’s hands and of the vicar’s head when it had been bowed for an instant today at the word river and then lifted because it had been asked to say Anton. When he spoke, he did not say a clever line, because cleverness serves only the first nice minute and then grows hungry.

“You cannot make a scarcity of what breath does,” he said. He said it to the hedge, because hedges understand things better than men when men are being watched. “You can make counting of the parts of it. You can put values on the edges so that someone with cold fingers can be persuaded it is warmer to have a list than a woman's hand. You can convince a boy that it is better to be thanked by a ribbon than by the look on his father’s face when the wood is in. But it is breath. It will go into whatever room will let it, and if you shut the doors, it will push under, and if you seal that, it will go out the chimney and come down next door and the next town will name its fields and sing badly and keep its grief in bowls.”

Vellum did not speak for a time, which is a form of respect in men who suspect they may not be loved and do not wish to do anything worse than they must. When he did, he kept his voice thin, perhaps because he did not know how to make it broad without sounding like someone he had hated. “My father gave my mother coupons for laughter,” he said, not looking at Elias and not looking away, because his eyes had been taught to behave at their work. “He gave her three a week and one extra at Easter and told her not to overspend because laughing made the neighbors think we were like them and he did not want to be like them. On Mondays she laughed when she burned the bread and got scolded for it because the coupon did not cover laughter at mistakes. On Saturdays she would stand by the window and look at the back yard and use them all in a swallow. I thought that was economy and grace. I thought that was how you kept a house from spilling. You will not persuade me with bowls.”

“I do not want to persuade you,” Elias said, because he had learned, slowly, that doing so can make a man hate truth for being clever. “I want to keep the town from being punished because your father ran his house like a counting book. You will go on being the sort of man whose hand writes smaller when he is ashamed. You will call it neatness and sometimes you will be right. You will look at the way people put cups down and think of putting them down in rows. No one will stop you thinking that. When you put the rows in other people’s houses you will be in my way. I will not let you. You may come and stand at the edge and watch a bowl and call it foolish and go away and not die of it. Or you may come with a cup, which would make both of us very tired. Either way, you will not count women’s laughter. It will go strange if you do.”

Vellum turned his head then, not toward Elias exactly, but toward the sound of a woman on the green laughing in a way she had been rationing her whole life, that donkey-bray surprised into grace which you hear on spring days and at funerals out of season. He watched the sound, which is a thing that can be done if you are patient, and for a second some piece of him that had been seven and had wanted to point thought very hard about climbing out of his shirt. He put his hand on his cuff, which he had whitened this morning so that no discussion of his person would take place without his consent, and he said, as if tasting does not count as appetite, “You will not think me a monster if I tell you I have written to men who will buy your fields with the numbers I have given them.”

“I will think you a clerk who has put his pen into another man’s land and expected the soil to take ink,” Elias said. He did not smile because there is no kindness in smiling at a man to whom you must say something honest. “They will come. They will carry rulers. They will stand in Daniel’s Oat and in Margaret’s Drop and ask where the lines are and expect to be told. And we will take them to the green and ask them to wait while we sing ill and ring bells wrong and feed them soup that is very good and speak the names of our dead in such a way that when they leave their rulers will have learned something unforgivable, which is that there are measures you cannot take and remain tidy. They will suspect we are untoward and be correct.”

“It will not last,” Vellum said, and his voice did not have triumph in it nor despair. It had the damp of below-rooms and a boy’s obedience. “You cannot win with bowls. A bowl breaks.”

“A bowl mends,” Elias answered, and the word, tiny and serviceable, went between them like an old coin that has passed so many hands it has become a prayer. “And even when it shatters, the floor keeps some of what was in it. You have been trying to win with pins. A pin rusts. I am not winning either, not in any way you would count. I am living long enough to know where the tea is kept. That, it turns out, is a form of victory if you have to choose one.” He inclined his head to Vellum, not as to a man he liked, which he did not, and not as to a man he pitied, which he was trying not to make into a habit, but as to a man he intended to continue to know until one of them died.

When he walked away, Quill slipped down from the hedge where he had been rude in every way a cat can be in the presence of a man who tries to regulate laughter. He wound himself between Elias’s ankles with exaggerated forgiveness, because he had climbed a field and dirtied his white feet and wished not to be told he was glorious. “He wants to be told someone will count him,” the cat said, which is as near to kindness as Quill gets with enemies who don’t have scales. “He thinks fair is numbers and not chairs carried and kettles offered and boys not told to hush. You will not persuade him, but you will make him late for his next cruelty and that matters as much as anything in a town.”

It was late when the new ledger went up, which is to say the old wall of the old posting house that no one had posted in for years because one man had been shot for the wrong thing there once upon a time and the wall had taken a dislike to messages. Tired hands with good chalk wrote on it not news and not orders and not anything that would earn anyone praise; they wrote kindnesses that had happened and the spoons that had been returned and the cups that had gone missing and had been found under beds and the chairs that had been carried and the chairs that would need carrying on Thursday because Mrs. Plumbly was coming to lay out her dead. They wrote in their own hands the line that Magdalene had learned to set and refused today and would not refuse tomorrow: already paid. Then under it, because men will be men and towns will be towns and there are rules that must be spoken and laughed at, they wrote: if you have not paid, do not fret; bring a pie.

At Elias’s table, the dot sat content as a seed in a dish and the truth card lay face down under it because truth lies better if you give it a small weight. He wrote on his list behind the broom mend and rest and then wrote borrow and lend and then wrote sing even if and then, because the day had asked more of him than a heroism and he had given it, he wrote sardines because Quill had been patient beyond reason. Quill leaped onto the chair with the look of a cat who has been promised something and intends to collect with a complaint, and he purred while he ate and made the tiny noise that sounds like tea water beginning to forgive a kettle. Andover breathed the way a house does when the baby has been put down and the father is keeping his chair quiet by force of will and the mother has taken off her shoes and will be found sleeping with one in her hand, and somewhere a man below a school put his pen down for a minute and looked at his empty hand as if it might have the right to be bare and did not know what to do with it and did nothing, which is a beginning if you have someone to make soup for you later.
